story:
Let me share with you my story...

Hello, my name is Roberta, but everyone calls me Bobbie.

It's a pleasure to meet you...

Like others, I came from a not so great background. Growing up as a ARMY brat, I lived in 13 states and two countries. It was a bit hard during my childhood because I jumped from school to school, then I lived on the streets as a young skate punk from the age 13.  Barely having any friends, I had been struggling to find myself ever since.

I can say I am a strong woman now because of the hardships and obstacles I had to go through.  But I always had hope in my heart.   

There were times in my life when I made bad decisions due to not having a mentor growing up, to teach me the values of life and my self-worth. What helped me get through everything was making jewelry and my love for music. They're my passions. 

I was lucky to find love unconditionally and acceptance at the age of 42.  He gave me the confidence to pursue my dreams.  Yes... I was lost for that long.

He believed in me and my vision and helped me launch my business. Fast forward two years, the only person who really and truly believed in me, is now my husband. I love him so much, he's my best friend.

I am the proud owner of Yoly Jewelry and I want to expand my business to own a boutique truck. 

It's time for me to take my business to the next level and to pursue my dream to own a store on wheels. It's so very hard to catch up and save with the price of living in the Bay Area. The reason I am running this campaign is because of limited real-estate, and skyrocketing rental prices. I cannot move out of the area since I am my father-in-law's care taker. 

I am looking for good-hearted supporters who have been there before, and had others give them a chance in life; who would understand and pay it forward to another good person. I cannot express the magnitude of the gratitude I feel, if you were to support me with my dream. 

I am a trailblazer of a women-owned small business, especially in this field.

Just give me that chance. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Let me explain my business for you to understand, and how much I will need and for what. 

$10,000 would reach my goal of building and designing my mobile boutique on wheels.

 Let me brake it down.

I have saved since last summer $2000 from the online sales and fairs.

~Buying a used trailer long enough to fill my merchandise and stock, will cost me between $7000-$8000

~Construction to gut everything out and fix it with shelves and props and lighting will be around $2000

~to paint and make sure the tires are good and no leaks from the roof will be a extra $2000

~I have a large truck to tow where I would need to set up and I can get insurance for what is needed. 

The perks is exciting because I can travel anywhere and everywhere on the weekends and I wont have to leave my little fur baby at home. Fairs, beaches, anywhere that has food courts and set up.

Every person who supports this campaign, and/or orders a perk from my list, will get a year of 10% off of anything in my store online or in person. It will be a "V.I.P." card which has a code on it for online shopping or you can bring the card in person and you will automatically get the 10% off. 

If for some reason if I do not reach my goal. I can promise you, I will not quit. I will safe-keep that investment and I will work hard at every fair I can get into, and save up and still buy my dream truck, It might take longer... but thats life. At least I tried. 

The Impact

Your contribution will make a difference because I am a nonstop worker until I archive my goal, so your investment will not be in vain. 

This project is very valuable to me, because I want something that makes me feel important and because I believe in hope and believe that anything is possible and anyone can achieve anything.

I made a pair of skull aviators sunglasses and sold of them for years. I had a picture emailed to me recently showing, Slash, from the band Guns and Roses wearing the pair of aviators I personally made. 

It felt good to know that Icons are wearing my art. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The only obstacle I may face to achieving my goal is if no one believed in me or my dream. I wrote down a complete business plans for myself and the future, and I know nothing can go wrong if I had the best support. 

I'm qualified to overcome any hurdle because I don't believe in quitting. I will also pay it forward. This can help the women in our community in knowing there are good people out there, who can and *will* support women-owned businesses, and I personally love to share my knowledge and experiances with young entrepreneurs as well. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please if you love my story, and you cannot donate, will you take the time to share my campaign in thoughts of helping me reach my goal? Please get the word out if you can. Make some noise! :) xoxoxo

All you need to do is please use the Indiegogo share tools, thats all there is to it.

Thank you so much for your time and support.

story:
The Lost & Found Project

1. Money will be used to fix donated camera (if possible photography courses for myself as well) 

2. I will explore the city capturing images that evoke feeling and may characterize scenarios we see play out in our society today.

3.Photographs will serve as inspiration and shall be partnered with an ephrastic poem or an essay and will be displayed in a gallery for the community to see, as well as published so that it can be distrubuted to others.

@note- I do not want to raise money for myself through this project I am using it as a way to cope with my stress and also as a way to raise awareness around issues in our community. All money raised here will go to fixing a donated camera that will be available to youth through Elephant Rebellion, a community collective of Artist activist and community Organizors, as well as other community affilliates of mine. I will use any remaining cash to buy an SD card, reproduce/print images and so on. 

( Example Not actual essay )     Photo #1 "Barren Land" 

The image above is one that I identify as a vivid metaphor for a scenario in our Society. In it we see a new toy truck, a set of swings as well as slides that look untouched, snow, trees that are withering away, and a sky that even gives off a chilling effect.  I see a reflection of what our children experience today in that image. 

       Often times youth are forced to make decisions that even some adults today would struggle with. They are thrown into a corrupt and cold world and often times have to fend for themselves. Not being afforded a childhood a lot of these youth grow up too quickly without love and compassion and make decisons that negatively impact their lives without realizing it. Leaving the next generation in an even worse state and condition. It does not have to be this way though, every youth deserves a childhood and we can fight against the violence, the sickness of this world to make sure they do.

story:
This artistic project aims to produce a high quality calendar printed on high quality paper with a luxury half-matt finish that can be hung anywhere from a small apartment to a luxury mansion.

Story 

 

Boring walls in boring homes all over the world, empty spaces filled with cheap décor and the lives around become as dull as the walls themselves.

It is time to change the dullness and create something of beauty, something any man who appreciates true beauty will understand and fall in love with.   Images of  beauty,  not crude and not offensive but beauty and captured in a moment to share for a lifetime.  The beauty found in a woman, her eyes, her smile, her mystery creates light and whispers a breeze that bring calm to the world around her and lift heartbeats just a notch.  The result is peaceful happiness, and with a hint of curiosity as the image speaks and you ask yourself a deep and thought provoking question every time you glimpse the beauty staring at you.



How to get involved

Now it is up to you to make this happen. The entire project can be fulfilled within 2 weeks of the finance being raised.  If you believe the images are beautiful and if you believe they should be shared then join this amazing and unique crowdfunding venture and of course tell others about it. 

Buy a calendar as a gift for a friend, buy one for yourself. The timeless beauty captured will amaze you and your friends. This is not a shameful pornographic calendar but an expression of beauty, the natural beauty of women that have broken the hearts of men and seen battles fought and won since time began. You can now own some of this beauty, trapped in time for you to adore. 

$30 seems a small price to pay for a work of art, and $30 buys you a work of mesmerising beauty for every month of the year in a 17”  13 page, luxury calendar.

$11 buys the digital PDF of the calendar allowing you display the beauty digitally all year round. 

Just want a single image?  Contact me and discus the image you want and I will have it printed on high quality photo paper and framed for $250 for a limited number of exclusive prints. 

The Goals

The calendars will be produced and delivered within 2 weeks from the end of the campaign should our milestones be met. 

The Calendars will be delivered in the UK and USA

The 2016 Calendar will be the first and the 2017 Calendar will follow.




Our goals: 
  • To provide the highest quality calendar, so that without shame in can be hung in Tajmahal, but also fit the van’s wall;
  •  To provide it on the area of USA and UK within 2 weeks from end of campaign
  • To provide continuation in the next year!





                        We will be more than happy to answer all your questions !


Photographer                                                                                                Model 

                                                                                                 



We did it. Photos are great. The calendar is sensory. There is no nudity, but beauty. There is no scream, but silence! But you here and now can shout to world, by clicking share and sharing it with your friends!

story:
DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT

In the Saharawi refugee camps located in the Sahara desert of Algeria (Africa) life can be very hard. Uprooted by a war they didn’t begin, the displaced people of Western Sahara reside there;  in a country that is not their own, in conditions that many would consider to be unlivable. Most of these people will never leave the boundaries of the camps. Most of them will never get to travel or see the world. They are prisoners, yet they have committed no crime.

So we decided we would bring the world to them.

Nearly a decade ago, we formed the Saharawi School of Ceramics for women; a non-profit academy dedicated to using the amazing power of art to uplift, educate and enlighten. We opened this school within the camps, to bring some joy and inspiration to the people that are trapped there.  Though the world of art is vast and incredible, you don’t need a plane ticket to see it. It is shared person to person. This has been the goal of our work at the academy, and the process of sharing the wonderful gift of art has changed the lives of our students almost as much as it has changed our own.


Currently the center is shared with Ceramics Cooperative consisting of about 20 women who finished their basic training at the School. Through this cooperative they have a job in a place they are practically intended to stay home and raise a family. They also learn a proffesion  that allows them to express their creativity and have a small source of income to help their families.

The school consists of one year of basic education in the various techniques of ceramics. Every year 10 women are selected by a simple test which measures their artistic skills. Once the education year is completed these women are given the option to join the cooperative where they work producing pottery for sale.



Up until now the school was funded by government grants, but due to the economic crisis in Spain the funding has stopped and, whith no help in sight, the school is in risk of closing it's doors.

So we decided to start this campaign, to reach out to the world for help. We want to reach out to those with a passion for art, and who understand the power it can have to change lives. We want to reach out to the people who care about the struggles of those who live beyond their borders.

Will you help us continue our work?



WHO ARE WE?

We are Alicia Fernandez Diaz, professor of ceramic, and Pilar Mas-Masia Sierra, coordinator of the project, from Spain.

To this date the project has been coordinated by the Federation of Support to the Saharawi People of Valencia (FASPS) and the City Council of Puzol (Valencia).
After traveling there several times a year and working voluntarily at the school during the past 10 years and loosing the public funding, we decided to turn to private funding to continue the school and allow that more women still benefit from this project in which so much time and effort has been invested.


WHAT WILL WE SPEND THE MONEY ON?

  • Airline tickets: Regular trips of the coordinator and professor of ceramic.
  • Visas
  • Stay
  • Material: Ceramic Material, solar panel to power the battery that powers the gas kiln, consumables, etc.
  • Shipping of the material: through the annual caravan bound for the camps.
  •  Repairs and maintenance of the school building
  •  Salary of the director and head of the center: It notes that without this figure, the project would have been impossible.In the camps, all proyects require a responsible and accountable to be in charge and respond adequately for the project. Salary director (€ 50 / month)
  • Salary two trainers: These two woman are those who have more seniority and experience and are responsible for educating the new students (30 € / month)
  • Expenses of the Crowdfunding campaign: Video production, shipping of perks and commission of the website.



AND IF WE MAKE MORE MONEY THAN THE AMOUNT WE ARE ASKING FOR?

The money will go to continue maintaining the school. The more money, the longer we can keep up with this project and the more women will benefit from it.

APPROXIMATE TIME TERM

The amount of money we hope to raise will fund the functioning of the school for two years. If we raise more money the school will last longer.

story:
FUU is the Bosnian acronym for Festival Ulične Umjetnosti meaning Street Art Festival. FUU is an open air street art festival in Sarajevo whose stages and performances will be held throughout the city, on locations both popular and forgotten. A unique event that directly engages the audience – in parks, streets, neighborhoods and avenues – with the goal of breathing in the spirit of culture and art in these areas.

The festival is a gift to Sarajevo and all of its citizens, regardless of their age, gender, social status or cultural background. It is art delivered to directly to streets, parks and in front of hallway doors.

During the festival the festival there will be performances and exhibitions that will  transform many parts of the city and leave a permanent mark on them, making them more interesting and beautiful. FUU will with each year give Sarajevo wonderful works of art that will stay there for good, and enrich the cultural and artistic landscape of the city. 

This festival is for everyone and every performance, exhibition, play or event related to the festival is absolutely free of charge.


Throughout the course of history Sarajevo has always been an intersection of different cultures and arts - a place where the East and West blend into each other. After years of conflict, the city is emerging from the ashes and is set to bring back the old glory that it was once known for.

However, we can't do this with the help of the government, as they continually fail to see the potential of art and culture and have cut funding to the most basic institutions like Museums (Yes, The National Museum is closed in Sarajevo due to a lack of government funding).

This does not discourage us. It only reminds us that at this moment it is important more than ever to launch this festival and raise awareness of the importance of art and culture and bring it back to the city we love - We owe it to Sarajevo.



FUU will take place from September 25th to 27th in over 20 locations all across Sarajevo. We have a developed program featuring domestic and international artists who will directly participate and contribute to FUU. 

Here's a list of some of our confirmed guests:

Inkie, Bristol, UK - London-based painter and street artist, originally from Clifton, Bristol. He is cited as being part of Bristol's graffiti heritage, along with Banksy, 3D and Nick Walker. (source: Wikipedia)

Vitkar Institute, Ljubljana, Slovenia - Performances of Slovenian Institute for contemporary performing arts and education, leaded by renowned choreographer Branko Potočan.

Sonic Studio, Sarajevo, Bosnia & Herzegovina - Shows, performances and installations of contemporary music and sound art by students and professors of the Music Academy in Sarajevo

Miron Milić, Zagreb, Croatia - Draughtsman, painter and street artists. Whether on notebooks or 15 meter walls, his illustrations are equally fascinating. 

These are just a few of our confirmed guests for this years festival. A detailed schedule and list of artists is available on our web site http://www.fuu.ba . 


At this point you may ask yourself, why do we need support if we already have confirmed artists visiting and have developed a festival program. 

The answer is simple and obvious: It costs.

While we have been able to get some support from private organizations, art lovers, media and volunteers in Sarajevo, however this will only be enough to cover the bare basics of making only a few events in three days.

As the goal of FUU is to involve as many artists as possible and truly make an impact on the city and establish a tradition of hosting FUU each year, we will need additional support.

WE need YOU!

If we can reach our goal of raising €25000  we can make FUU a complete three day experience and involve as many artists and locations in Sarajevo as possible and set the foundations of creating a festival that will get stronger every year.

Together, we could put art back into the spotlight!

Here is a short breakdown of what additional activities and events we can make (along with covering the costs of our current ones) with amount of money we will raise: 



  • FUU video log and documentary. We will be able to record the performances and exhibitions and make a short documentary film about the festival, the artists and the people behind them.
  • Cover the costs for performing the play "Alice in Wonderland" created by the students of the three Art Academies in Sarajevo (Performing Arts, Music and Fine Arts), in the botanical gardens of the closed National Museum. 
  • Create bloc parties in two Sarajevo municipalities (Novi Grad and Novo Sarajevo) featuring graffiti artists, DJ's and the students from the Music Academy of Sarajevo.


Everything from above + 

  • Project: Camera Obscura on the streets by artist Dženat Dreković. - Take photos of people passing by the streets of Sarajevo and the participants/artists of the festival and print out these photographs to be put on exhibition on the closing of the festival.
  • Creating graffiti murals on three more different locations in Sarajevo by local graffiti artists.
  • 3D video mapping performance by Miško Nećak on one of the landmark Sarajevo buildings (History Museum or Ars Aevi)
  • Uncovering the life-sized sculpture of Everyman, by artist Lejla Čehajić, which will permanently stay in Sarajevo.



By reaching our goal of €25000 we could make all of the above happen plus we would have the opportunity to create a contest among among young Architects and Designers to submit projects that would contribute to the partial revival of ruined and neglected locations in Sarajevo. Their creative solutions would make Sarajevo a more beautiful place and at the same time empower and encourage youth to step out with their own ideas and projects and most importantly leave their permanent mark on the city together with FUU.  

Additional funds would go to making the selected project happen and prepare the same process for next year's FUU.

All of the funds are going directly to making this festival happen for Sarajevo and its citizens.

Funding FUU will get you many different perks. Here are some of them:


We are able to ship the perks (apart from a few available worldwide) to the US, Europe, Canada and Australia. Most of the perks will be shipped after the festival. Click on them for more detail. 


FUU is every man and woman who loves art and believes it should be out there for everyone. The idea of the festival first initiated by renowned Sarajevan director Aleš Kurt who is the heart of the FUU.

After Aleš presented his idea to us, we started working tirelessly on making FUU happen. We are:


You can also help us by spreading the word about FUU to your friends and work associates. Everyman would love that everyone knows about FUU!  Every contribution counts. Also, if you are based in Sarajevo you can volunteer  for the festival from September 25th to 27th (see website for more detail).
story_txt:
FUU is the Bosnian acronym for Festival Ulične Umjetnosti meaning Street Art Festival. FUU is an open air street art festival in Sarajevo whose stages and performances will be held throughout the city, on locations both popular and forgotten. A unique event that directly engages the audience – in parks, streets, neighborhoods and avenues – with the goal of breathing in the spirit of culture and art in these areas. The festival is a gift to Sarajevo and all of its citizens, regardless of their age, gender, social status or cultural background. It is art delivered to directly to streets, parks and in front of hallway doors.
During the festival the festival there will be performances and exhibitions that will  transform many parts of the city and leave a permanent mark on them, making them more interesting and beautiful. FUU will with each year give Sarajevo wonderful works of art that will stay there for good, and enrich the cultural and artistic landscape of the city.  
This festival is for everyone and every performance, exhibition, 
play or event related to the festival is absolutely free of charge.

Throughout the course of history Sarajevo has always been an intersection of different cultures and arts - a place where the East and West blend into each other. After years of conflict, the city is emerging from the ashes and is set to bring back the old glory that it was once known for.However, we can't do this with the help of the government, as they continually fail to see the potential of art and culture and have cut funding to the most basic institutions like Museums (Yes, The National Museum is closed in Sarajevo due to a lack of government funding). This does not discourage us. It only reminds us that at this moment it is important more than ever to launch this festival and raise awareness of the importance of art and culture and bring it back to the city we love - We owe it to Sarajevo. 
FUU will take place from September 25th to 27th in over 20 locations all across Sarajevo. We have a developed program featuring domestic and international artists who will directly participate and contribute to FUU. 
Here's a list of some of our confirmed guests: Inkie, Bristol, UK - London-based painter and street artist, originally from Clifton, Bristol. He is cited as being part of Bristol's graffiti heritage, along with Banksy, 3D and Nick Walker. (source: Wikipedia) 

Vitkar Institute, Ljubljana, Slovenia - Performances of Slovenian Institute for contemporary performing arts and education, leaded by renowned choreographer Branko Potočan.

Sonic Studio, Sarajevo, Bosnia & Herzegovina - Shows, performances and installations of contemporary music and sound art by students and professors of the Music Academy in Sarajevo


Miron Milić, Zagreb, Croatia -  Draughtsman, painter and street artists. Whether on notebooks or 15 meter walls, his illustrations are equally fascinating.  


These are just a few of our confirmed guests for this years festival. A detailed schedule and list of artists is available on our web site http://www.fuu.ba . 






At this point you may ask yourself, why do we need support if we already have confirmed artists visiting and have developed a festival program. 
The answer is simple and obvious: It costs.
While we have been able to get some support from private organizations, art lovers, media and volunteers in Sarajevo, however this will only be enough to cover the bare basics of making only a few events in three days. As the goal of FUU is to involve as many artists as possible and truly make an impact on the city and establish a tradition of hosting FUU each year, we will need additional support. 
WE need YOU! 
If we can reach our goal of raising €25000  we can make FUU a complete three day experience and involve as many artists and locations in Sarajevo as possible and set the foundations of creating a festival that will get stronger every year. 
Together, we could put art back into the spotlight!
Here is a short breakdown of what additional activities and events we can make (along with covering the costs of our current ones) with amount of money we will raise: 






FUU video log and documentary. We will be able to record the performances and exhibitions and make a short documentary film about the festival, the artists and the people behind them.

Cover the costs for performing the play "Alice in Wonderland" created by the students of the three Art Academies in Sarajevo (Performing Arts, Music and Fine Arts), in the botanical gardens of the closed National Museum.  

Create bloc parties in two Sarajevo municipalities (Novi Grad and Novo Sarajevo) featuring graffiti artists, DJ's and the students from the Music Academy of Sarajevo. 


Everything from above + 
Project: Camera Obscura on the streets by artist Dženat Dreković. - Take photos of people passing by the streets of Sarajevo and the participants/artists of the festival and print out these photographs to be put on exhibition on the closing of the festival. 

Creating graffiti murals on three more different locations in Sarajevo by local graffiti artists. 

3D video mapping performance by Miško Nećak on one of the landmark Sarajevo buildings (History Museum or Ars Aevi)
Uncovering the life-sized sculpture of Everyman, by artist Lejla Čehajić, which will permanently stay in Sarajevo.





By reaching our goal of €25000 we could make all of the above happen plus we would have the opportunity to create a contest among among young Architects and Designers to submit projects that would contribute to the partial revival of ruined and neglected locations in Sarajevo. Their creative solutions would make Sarajevo a more beautiful place and at the same time empower and encourage youth to step out with their own ideas and projects and most importantly leave their permanent mark on the city together with FUU.   
Additional funds would go to making the selected project happen and prepare the same process for next year's FUU. All of the funds are going directly to making this festival happen for Sarajevo and its citizens. Funding FUU will get you many different perks. Here are some of them: 
  




We are able to ship the perks (apart from a few available worldwide) to the US, Europe, Canada and Australia. Most of the perks will be shipped after the festival. Click on them for more detail. 
   

FUU is every man and woman who loves art and believes it should be out there for everyone. The idea of the festival first initiated by renowned Sarajevan director Aleš Kurt who is the heart of the FUU. After Aleš presented his idea to us, we started working tirelessly on making FUU happen. We are: 









You can also help us by spreading the word about FUU to your friends and work associates. Everyman would love that everyone knows about FUU!  Every contribution counts. Also, if you are based in Sarajevo you can volunteer  for the festival from September 25th to 27th (see website for more detail).

story:
I am pleased and excited to announce that the U.S. Navy has formally selected Saturday, November 21, 2015, as the date of the commissioning of the USS Milwaukee (LCS-5).   On this date, the U.S. Navy will commission the 5th Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) of the Freedom Class of modern warships in Veteran’s Park on the Milwaukee lakefront.  

The commissioning ceremony celebrates the Navy’s official act of placing USS Milwaukee in active fleet service.  The formal commissioning ceremony is rooted in century’s old naval tradition.  It is an exciting event to hear the ship’s sponsor give the first order to the ship's company: "Man our ship and bring her to life!"    The picture below depicts the commissioning of the USS Freedom (LCS-1) on the Milwaukee lakefront in 2008.

USS Milwaukee was launched in December 2013 and is currently undergoing comprehensive testing in an underway evolution referred to as “sea trials.”  She is in the process of completing her final outfitting and will begin her transit down to Milwaukee from Marinette, Wisconsin, in mid-November.  

We now have a date for the great event and it will not be long before the City of Milwaukee is burgeoning with Navy dignitaries, sailors, and guests.  The ceremony will bring over 15,000 people to Milwaukee’s lakefront. It will provide abundant opportunity for corporations, small businesses, individuals, and institutions to collaborate and support the Great Lake’s naval legacy and our City and State’s important role in maritime technological advances.  Most importantly we can show the world the support that the State of Wisconsin and the City of Milwaukee’s gives to our US Navy and the sailors that make her the world’s greatest Navy, projecting force and defending our freedom across the world.  

This memorable celebration will only be achieved through your generosity.  I ask that you please aid in the sponsorship of this important event.  It is an opportunity for you to demonstrate your support for our military personnel and the great people of the City of Milwaukee and the State of Wisconsin.  

Information is included highlighting ways you can directly support the U.S. Navy’s Commissioning of USS Milwaukee.   Please contact me directly at dirk@msigeneral.com or Alan Perlstein our Resource Development Action Team Leader at aperlstein@m-werc.org with any questions you may have about your contribution. Thank you in advance for your commitment and generosity.

story:
The Angel Project

Brief Description:

The Angel Project is a visual mastication of gay social-network-enforced stereotypes masquerading as the potential for creation of Judaochristian Apocryphal 'Renaissance' panels.

Long Description:

            The goal is to create an exhibit that outlines the creation of 9 photographic artworks of a homo-eroticized pantheon of male gendered archangels surrounding a Pantocrator type Jesus [Christ the Pantocrator, Christus Mortis, and Christus Triumphans].

            Beyond the actual fetishization implied by making obsessive and detailed works, down to the intensive creation of props I want to have cohesion from image to image so that they can function together as a 9 part panel.

            My goal is to talk about stereotypes in a way that traps viewers into confronting stereotypes of religion, religious views on homosexuality, misquotation and apocrypha, and stereotypes within and without the gay community.

            I would ultimately want to use fairly accepted methods of creating a solid photographic image to increase the idea of the importance of the quality of the visual language, while not making overly supportive gestures to what I'm creating (morally speaking).

            Preferably the approach to this senior thesis is as a further exploration of techniques I have not tried incorporated into ideas I already find intriguing to further my experience in visual story telling and in art direction.

story:
Die Urbane Kunstkammer

Partizipativ. Dialogisch. Unkommerziell. Gleichberechtigt. Niedrigschwellig. Zeitlich und räumlich begrenzt. Prozesshaft. Interaktiv. Experimentell.

Das Konzept

Das von der Hamburger Künstlerin Jana Fux entwickelte Konzept stützt sich auf den Begriff der Kunst- und Wunderkammer, welcher erstmals im späten 16. Jahrhundert von Samuel Quicceberg verwendet wurde. Es handelte sich dabei um ein Archiv der wundersamen Dinge, das Künstlern und Kennern zur Erforschung der Welt und des Erlangen eines Beweises der „Existenz eines übergeordneten, alles einenden Prinzips“ (Patrick Mauriès „Das Kuriositätenkabinett“, 2011) nutzten. Dazu wurden Objekte aus der Natur (naturalia) und Kunst (artificialia) mit dem Wunsch nach enzyklopädischer Vollständigkeit zusammengetragen, geordnet, kategorisiert und ausgestellt, um den Kosmos im Kleinen (universe en miniature) nachzubilden und begreifbar zu machen. Damit gelten diese Kunst- und Wunderkammern heute als Vorläufer der heutigen Museen.

Diesem Gedanken folgend versuchen wir uns in urbanen, also städtischen Räumen, durch künstlerischen Austausch und möchten dabei Weltsichten verhandeln. Das heißt unsere Sammlung ist nicht von einer Person gemacht, sondern von sehr vielen, mit den unterschiedlichsten Erfahrungen, Fähigkeiten, kulturellen und künstlerischen Praktiken und Überzeugungen. In einem kontinuierlichen Prozess wurden also innerhalb eines halben Jahres Ideen geschmiedet und gemeinsam werden dieser in einer Produktionswoche realisiert.

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

Seit Beginn des Jahres treffen wir uns wöchentlich im Gängeviertel, schmieden Pläne und kochen dort für Alle, die eben vorbeischauen, dort wohnen, arbeiten und an dem bunten Treiben im Viertel teilnehmen. Aus dem Wunsch eine Ausstellung zu realisieren ist ein Festival mit 50 Künstlern und Künstlerinnen mitsamt buntem Rahmenprogramm entstanden. In den Schaffensprozess sind rund 100 Personen involviert, die allesamt unentgeltlich am Projekt beteiligt sind.

In der Produktionswoche nehmen sich unsere Techniker eine Woche Zeit und lassen Ihre entgeltliche Arbeit ruhen, unsere Künstler und Künstlerinnen bauen, hängen und schrauben sich mit uns durch die Woche und richten gemeinsam Ihre Ausstellungsräume, unsere Kunstvermittlerinnen lassen Ihre Köpfe dampfen, unser Bau-Team pinselt, spachtelt und hämmert, unser PR-Team hat Hamburg bei Plakat- und Flyer-touren erlaufen und wir? 

Wir wissen, das wir mit eurer Hilfe Alles schaffen können!

Diese Kampagne kommt daher vor allem dem Transport des technischen Equipments und der zahlreichen Kunstwerke, der technischen Realisierung, der Möglichkeit auch in Zukunft solch ein wunderbares Projekt zu stemmen und einem unbeschwertem Tun zu Gute. Soll heißen, dass wir unseren professionellen und ehrenamtlichen Anspruch keineswegs durch das Fehlen von finanziellen Mitteln mindern möchten.

Dieses Projekt funktioniert nur mit euch - mit eurer finanziellen Unterstützung, eurem Interesse und durch eure Interaktion mit den Kunstschaffenden.

Mit euren Spenden haben wir alle den Kopf frei, Szenerien zu entwerfen, Ideen in die Tat umzusetzen, euch zum Nachdenken zu bewegen und eine unvergessliche Ausstellung zu stemmen. 

Ihr könnt oder möchtet uns kein Geld geben?

Wir freuen uns über euren Besuch vom 25. - 27. November und natürlich über Werbung für unsere Kampagne sowie das Projekt.

Wir Danken

Dem Berufsbildungswerk Hamburg für die Unterstützung mit einem Team von Auszubildenden beim Bau von Ausstellungsmobiliar und dem Auf- sowie Abbau.  

Der René S. Spiegelberger Stiftung für die Unterstützung bei den Druckkosten.

Dem Gängeviertel in Hamburg für die Kooperation und die Räumlichkeiten.

Mehr Infos auch unter

http://www.dieurbanekunstkammer.org/

facebook.com/urbanekunstkammer

facebook.com/kunstundraumev

story:
Summary

  • I am a rising artist who paints acrylic on canvas. For a long time, I have been painting figurative style; and this year I began portraying memorable footwear and wine bottles. These collections have caused quite a roar in the artist community, and have been selected to be exhibit at the San Diego Fine Art Exhibition (3-6 Nov), and the opening night of the Pappalecco Art Showcase (11 Oct).
  • Cecilia created a virtual art gallery I can exhibit my artwork and sell it. Selling art online is expensive, and participating in art exhibitions and road shows is even more expensive. I need your help.
  • Contributors will help with the costs associated with exhibitions and shows, website expenses, marketing and renting a small studio (if the campaign is ultra successful and I receive a lot of commission artwork orders in the process :-)). Your empowering this project has a domino effect because I will be able to empower others through my art. Moreover, I donate in turn to several organizations like Saint Jude's Children Research and Hospital, The SEAL Foundation and others that you can see on the website (https://www.art-meta.com/cecilia-anastos---pain...)

What We Need & What You Get

  • The rising artist exhibition wall cost $1500 (3-6 Nov), and the upcoming road shows cost between $100 and $500. The website, and the Etsy and Shopify stores cost an average of $120 a month to run, and each time I need to promote the new paintings in Facebook and LinkedIn I need to spend at least $150 on each campaign to gain new buyers, followers, etc.
  • Your contributing to this project is an investment on a promising rising artist whose works have been already judged by experts and accepted at impressive venues like the San Diego Fine Art Exhibition on 3-6 Nov at Balboa Park, San Diego, CA, and the Little Italy Artshow (April 2017)
  • Based on your level of contribution, you could receive original paintings or limited fine print editions. Do you remember Vincent Van Gogh? Nobody would give a broken penny for his work and today people are paying millions of dollars for it. :-) You could also end up owning a painting that in a few years would be worth a fortune.
  • If I do not reach the goal, the funds that I collected will be applied to cover the cost I have already incurred so far.

The Impact

Art is one of the healthiest ways of expression, and through art we also want to make a difference in our communities:

  • You as a contributor and art lover will feel empowered by allowing me to continue exhibiting my work and make a living from it.
  • I, the artist, empowers and encourages others who have the skills inside but are not sure how to shine. Since I decided to start selling my art, I have empowered four more women to do the same: Sheri, Janice, Jamie, and Jasmina. 
  • Still undecided? Send me an email and I will gladly answer any questions you might have: curator@art-meta.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you cannot contribute financially, get the word out and make some noise about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you very much for helping me realize this dream of making a living through art.

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
If you cannot contribute financially, get the word out and make some noise about my campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you very much for helping me realize this dream of making a living through art.

story:
This year, Donald Trump drew attention to the so-called charitable activities of his foundation, by using the funds to purchase two portraits of himself. When we investigated this story, we discovered something equally odd. Donald Trump has given only $30,000 to his own foundation over the course of the last ten years—less money to his own foundation than it costs to run Art F City’s own non-profit program for a single year. So we propose a wager: If our readers can raise more than $30,000, the minimum amount we need to support our operations for the year, we will reward our first 100 supporters with the limited edition print, "The names of Drumpf" by famed artist and satirist William Powhida.

What's more, you will be supporting our essential artist-centered projects like: 

  • The Art F City blog. Because you need something in your feed beyond partisan bickering. Our coverage includes smart, critical perspectives that focus on artist led efforts. 
  • We Are SO Not Getting the Security Deposit Back; a Guide to Defunct Artist-Run Spaces. A zine project we launched this spring and will release spring 2017. 
  • Exhibitions in New York, Mexico City and beyond. 
  • Stay in New York, an affordable workspace conference to be held in the spring of 2017. 

And for those hoping to get even more than a print of Drumpt, we've got extraordinary perks lined up. Free admittance to our special VIP salad party in Miami this year. Studio visits with Paddy Johnson A tour of selected New York Trump properties and an assessment of their lobby art by AFC’s Michael Anthony Farley and Paddy Johnson. 

So donate to Art F City today and get your friends to do the same. Remember, if we don't make our goal, no one gets the Powhida print, and AFC doesn't continue its trailblazing support of artist-centered projects. Surely that's a cause worth giving to!

Art F City is a 501c3 and non-profit registered in the state of New York. Your donations are 100 percent tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

story:
Short Summary

Parallel universes have begun to merge, creating wormholes and wreaking havoc.  Two unlikely historical figures fight for survival as they search for the truth behind these mysterious happenings. 

Our adventure begins with Ernest Hemingway, who is quietly fishing off the coast of Cuba. Out of the blue, a wormhole opens up; Amelia Earhart and her airplane zip by, crashing into the ocean. Hemingway’s instincts take control; he plunges in to rescue any survivors but resurfaces holding a small girl dressed in pilot’s clothing. Amelia awakens the next day, unable to remember any aspects of her former life, other than her first name. Ernest and Amelia exchange introductions as they try to make sense of recent events. During their discussion, a mysterious creature materializes before them and calls himself Bob the Time Traveling Spirit Fish.

Bob explains that he can create safe time-traveling portals and detect time-related anomalies in their universe. Due to these powers, Bob has an immense knowledge of time-travel and parallel universes. Still unsure, the duo has Bob clarify recent events. They discover Amelia’s wormhole was the catalyst setting in motion the decay and pending destruction of the multiverse.  Bob informs Ernest and Amelia as to how normal objects pass through wormholes and how they’re usually twisted by their turbulent nature. However, Bob’s powers allow them to travel securely and without any negative consequences throughout these time rifts. In doing so, they’ll be able to uncover evidence and track down whomever is responsible for this disaster.

Over the course of six issues, this ragtag trio jumps one time-rift to another, they uncover clues, and meet a wide arrange of past, present, and time-distorted characters. Eventually, Bob’s powers are able to pinpoint the location of Amelia’s plane and uncover her true identity. In a parallel universe, Fred Noonan, co-pilot to Amelia Earhart, survived the horrific plane crash. Noonan had dedicated the rest of his life to save his partner; after years of trial and error, he creates and opens a wormhole that can save Amelia.  
 

Who is the creator of this comic?

Tyler Bray is both the artist and author for this upcoming series. He is local artist, holding a degree in Studio Art, and has a passion for Ernest Hemingway.
 

What I Need & What You Get

This Indiegogo campaign is for the first two issues of Ernest Hemingway and Amelia Earhart in the Tales of Time.  I need to raise money for a professional 11x17 scanner and printer, book binding supplies, and printing costs.

With your help, I will be able to produce the first two issues in this series, with a projected six or more issues to follow.

In order to bring this book to life, I use traditional comic book making tools of the trade, such as ink, watercolor, and brush work. When the art is completed, I will then scan it, and touch up any flaws or mistakes in the art. From there, the files containing the comic pages and covers will be sent to the printer. Finally, the completed comic book will be bound and ready to be shipped out to you, my awesome supporters!

I plan on printing 100 copies of the first book to bring to comic book conventions and art shows. This will be on top of the issues printed especially for backers who want a physical copy or earn one in my perks! I will also be offering the first issue as a digital download.

Once the first issue is made available to the public, I will immediately begin work on the second book and continue the trend!

To show my appreciation to those who fund and help me reach my goal, I have created some amazing perks.  We will be offering 3 unique, high quality art prints, all splash pages made and used in the upcoming series.



Depending on your pledge level, you can chose from one, two, or even all three prints. If you pledge high enough, you can even chose to receive one of the original pieces of art the prints are based on. 



For the highest levels, I will be dedicating comic books to the highest donors.

The Impact

I am excited to bring an original, unique, and above all entertaining story into the world. I have a passion for story telling, especially sequential art, and I am looking forward to adding my voice to the ever expanding chorus of independent, creator owned comic books. So, get ready for some great story telling and amazing art work as you lose yourself in time with Ernest Hemingway and Amelia Earhart!

Risks & Challenges

My biggest challenge will getting the funds to bring this story to life. I am an independent creator with a beautiful family to support and bills to pay. Despite working full time, paying for the production of a brand new comic series by myself is a little more than I can swing at the moment...and this is exactly why crowdfunding is so awesome! If you donate in the name of entertaining fun, I will deliver!

Other Ways You Can Help

It is very important to me that this comic book excites and entertains you.  This project is something I am having so much fun working on and I want you to share in that with me.

So, thanks for being a part of this and helping me spread the work and complete this first issue.  I can’t wait to share it with all of you.

story:
Who is Ascension?

Ascension is a community of Thinkers, Makers, Lovers, and Creators from the Bay Area building Big Art for the Playa this year.  It all started with a transformational gathering held last year. We built a stage entirely out of salvaged materials. Artists came together to share their passion and talents. We did something unheard of at a festival before (aside from not selling entry tickets): we turned off the music at dinner time and everyone gathered at a 200 ft. table to share a meal that we all created. It was a powerful, collaborative experience that echoed our ancestral pastimes.

More than just a Burning Man Art Vehicle: A Mobile Storytelling Device

Ascension continues to branch into different sustainable and creative projects. PAVO is a transformational story telling device that will debut at Burning Man 2016. PAVO the peacock tells the story of Ascension: improving yourself and connecting to the environment around you. The peacock is a symbol that represents the beauty that can be achieved when we endeavor to better ourselves. It’s about showing your true colors, living your life as a work of art by putting LOVE into everything that you do, and creating positive energy around you.

The Impact

By contributing to this project, you are investing in the future. Our vision for PAVO is to build a betterment mobile, showing up in times of need to rally the community towards action. For example, a “beach party” becomes a “party with a purpose” instead. PAVO will provide rewarding music as party-goers dance while they clean, leaving the beach more vibrant than before. This is just one example of the betterment PAVO can provide.

What We Need

After much thought, planning, and discussion we respectfully ask you, our friends, our family, our people -- to support us in bringing our vision for PAVO to life. We have been building for months and still need funds in order to reveal PAVO at Burning Man 2016. The bulk of the energy will go toward: building the platform (at the BoxShopSF), repairs to the vehicle, lighting of the feathers (consulting with Symmetry Labs), and the sound system (Tectonic Audio Labs & Know Audio). Our plan for PAVO’s construction is carefully mapped out (and detailed below). We have been working for months and we are so close but we need your help to bring this project to life!

$25,000?! What for?

PAVO projected costs:

  • Structural steel for frame and feathers: $2,500
  • Vehicle repairs: $3,500
  • Lighting of 10,000 LEDs: $5,000
  • Fabrication services (laser/plasma cutting, structural analysis): $2,500
  • Transportation & metal shop rental : $3,500
  • Awesome fur and fabric: $1,500
  • Artistic touch through design, paint, and fiberglass fabrication: $1,500
  • Sound equipment: Donated by some very amazing people
  • Vehicle: Donated by a loving Pavo team member

Fees and Reward Fulfillment: $5,000

  • Indiegogo + credit card fees: $1,800
  • Reward shipping cost (estimated): $500
  • Reward materials cost (estimated): $2,700

Our Way of Saying Thanks

We’ve designed custom Tokens of Appreciation exclusively for our community to say thank you for the support. Check out the donation perks below, and visit the Ascension Facebook page to see more pics of our progress.

This project would not have come this far if it weren't for the help of many close family, friends and amazing people that believe in our community!  So Big HUGS and lots of LOVE to you all!

Steve Belale, Lead Artistic Designer www.stevebelale.com

Victor Esposto, Lead Fabricator & Designer

Nick Chirichillo, Lead Visioneer & Designer/Fabricator

Ryan Cooke, Structural Engineer

David Firestone & Denny Mayer, Techtonic Audio Labs

Pascal Pincosy, Know Audio 

Trip Vest & Kyle Fleming, Symmetry Labs

Bob & Bobby Joe Resch,  Princeton Welding 

Andy Wallace, Maxx Metals 

Charles Gadeken, The BoxShop

Michael Ogata, Ogata Productions

Joe & Vince Trapani, Trap's Tire & Auto Center

Our Ascension Families: Ascension Gathering & Ascension: Rising in Love

All of our families and friends who've given feedback throughout this process and continue to support us.

story:
Short Summary

  •  8ROJO has become a distinct voice in Western Canada and abroad for its interdisciplinary performances, which combine unique artistry and innovative productions.The group, based in Calgary, Alberta, devises these integrative presentations of  images in motion which strive to cultivate meaningful dialogue between audience and performer. 8ROJO focuses on creating work that is challenging, relevant and profound for both artists and audiences alike.

  • This is an opportunity for 8ROJO members  Kristin Eveleigh, Marcy Lannan, Norma Lewis, Patrick Quinn, Michael Rogers and Javier Vilalta to attend the 2016 edition of the STOFF festival in Stockholm, Sweden. 

  • After Mexico City and Prague; Stockholm will host 8ROJO's third international presentation. STOFF is considered one of the most important festivals for indie arts in Europe. Being selected for the 2016 edition of the festival is a unique opportunity to be showcased among risk-taking interdisciplinary artists from across the globe. We will be proud representatives of Canada, Alberta and Calgary. 

What We Need 

  • We hope to raise the amount of CAD $5,000, in order to help us complete our funding initiative.
  • In case we don't reach our funding goal through this campaign, any money collected will be used to cover shipping and accommodations for the six members of our group who will attend.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us spread the work by letting others know about our crowdfunding initiative. Any amount helps! 
  •  We would like to thank you for your support towards our latest creative adventure.

story:
The Platform has been in operation since June 2015.  Since then we've had about 3 shows a month featuring performing artists of every type you can imagine. We've had 80 year olds in our audiences as well as 8 year olds, and everywhere in between. We've created countless connections between folks in the community that wouldn't have a place or reason to meet otherwise. The Platform was born out a love for the arts and this community and we couldn’t be more thankful for all of the support we’ve received so far.

We’ve learned a lot in the past year. One of the things we’ve learned is that there is not much profit in a performance venue in a town of 5,000 in rural West Central, Minnesota, particularly when you make an effort to pay artists for their time and travels. There are significant costs associated with maintaining the space (rent, promotional costs, insurance, equipment, etc.) All of our revenue is generated by cover fees and previous donations. Your donations will be used to supplement our funds and cover some of the aforementioned costs.

This time around a donation gets you a space on our east wall. We’ve divided the wall into vinyl record cover and CD cover sized spaces. We have options for groups and individuals. We are working with local artists to design and paint the spaces, or if you’d prefer you can come in and paint the space yourself. You can have the space simply say your name or a brief message (because we are all ages, we will be filtering these messages). In our past fundraiser we struggled to keep up with all of the perks we offered. This time around we are keeping things much simpler to be easier to keep up with. You can expect your wall space to be filled with in a month to a month and a half of your donation.

We hope you’ll consider donating to #fillourwalls. The Platform has been a place of passion and joy for many individuals in the past year. Please contribute to continue our goal of community building and nurturing the arts in West Central Minnesota. Thank you for your time and thanks in advance if you choose to donate!

story:
Rebuild the Wood Kiln @ Baltimore Clayworks

Baltimore Clayworks’ mission is to develop, promote and sustain an artist-centered community, which provides outstanding artistic, educational and collaborative programs in the ceramic arts.  Founded in 1980 by a group of nine community-minded ceramic artists, Baltimore Clayworks has developed a strong local and global reputation for artists’ development coupled with sustained community engagement. 

Now approaching its 36th year, Clayworks continues to grow, evolve and connect deeply with Baltimore city and community. Baltimore Clayworks brings the most talented national and international ceramic artists to both our campus in Mt. Washington and our community sites in under-resourced neighborhoods across the region. Through classes, workshops, lectures, events and exhibitions, Clayworks reaches youth, adults, families and seniors regardless of their social or economic status, by providing high-quality ceramic arts instruction for the betterment of all.

Each year Baltimore Clayworks has 12 artists in residence, 4 visiting artists and 20-25 exhibitions in our galleries in Mt. Washington. Clayworks has over 60 professional teaching artists and nearly 400 additional exhibiting artists throughout the year. Annually we teach over 1,500 students in our studios in Mt. Washington and over 3,000 students through our Community Arts programs throughout the City and surrounding area.

Baltimore Clayworks is committed to making the arts accessible to those who otherwise would have limited or no access, bringing professional ceramic artists to Baltimore to work with youth and senior adults at our satellite studios and in other spaces in their own communities. By partnering with organizations already imbedded in the life of the neighborhoods and developing art-making programs that meet the interests of the community, Baltimore Clayworks has successfully worked with broad and diverse groups of residents in Baltimore for over three decades.

This rings true for our community wood fire program. We offer community members the ability to fire most unique and offerings at Baltimore Clayworks - the opportunity to fire in our 2 chambered wood burning Noborigama kiln. With its final firing in May, we now need the community to support the rebuild the kiln this summer in order to continue firings as early as August!

What We Need & What You Get

As one of the most publicly used wood kilns in the area, and across the county, Clayworks is passionate about the opportunity to provide the wood firing opportunity to the surrounding community. The rebuild of the kiln will cost $25,000. With the support of one of our generous students, Suzan Rouse on behalf of the the Awalt Family Foundation, we have $10,000 to put toward the project – now we just need the remaining $15,000 to get it started! This is where you come in to help. Over the next 30 days, we will raise these funds through this online platform.

NEW NEWS! Thanks to Dwight and Kirsten Johnson for donating $1,000 to the campaign! Also, thanks to our trustee, James Turnbull; he helped us secure a 100% in-kind donation of bricks from RESCO for the rebuild.

The total $25,000 will fund an expert at rebuilding this type of kiln from Kentucky. He will be with us making plans, executing and building on-site during the process. Funds will also support materials and supplies, which include items such as: Concrete Block, Fire Bricks, Fire Insulation, Coarse Grog, Clay, Sand, and Cement. It also includes tool rentals, labor and instruction.

At each level of giving, you will receive fantastic perks, ranging from $10 (anyone can do this, right!) all the way up to $25,000, which would cover the entire project and get you naming rights to this beautiful new kiln!

At the $25 'Helping Hand' level, snag a ceramic pin/magnet that you can display or wear to show your support of Clayworks and this project.

If you give at the $50 'cups, Cups, CUPS' level, you will have the opportunity to participate in one of our Cup-a-Thons this summer - providing you the opportunity to get your hands in clay, make your own cup and put it in the first firing of the newly rebuilt wood kiln this summer! (You will also have the option to participate in the cup-a-thons at all higher giving levels, too.) 

Those giving over $100 will get a Clayworks Artist Made cup, bowl, vase or other work out of the first firing of the rebuilt wood kiln!

Giving at levels of $500 or more, you will have the opportunity to attend and learn about the project and Clayworks during our special brunch at the newly rebuilt wood kiln!

Those giving at higher levels of $2,500 or more will receive special recognition and signage opportunities in the galleries and/or classroom building, along with getting a ceramic piece out of the first firing and other opportunities for special get-together and learning experiences.

Finally, if you are really looking to make a significant gift and impact on our community, a $10,000 gift would match Suzan Rouse's gift and provide you with some amazing perks. Or, if you give $25,000, this would cover the expenses of the entire project, plus allow for funding to be set aside to cover future materials, supplies, repairs and help with our wood kiln manager's salary. Naming rights of the kiln would be the biggest perk and would provide the $25,000 donor the opportunity to have signage at the kiln and throughout our facilities and other promotions.

This is an ALL OR NOTHING campaign. Unfortunately, we cannot move forward with the rebuild of the kiln if we do not obtain the full $25,000. That’s why it’s so important that we get your help today – big or small – every amount matters.

The Impact

Clayworks has over 300 individuals and groups that use the wood kiln, year after year. With interest at this level, Clayworks fires our wood kiln up to 2-3 times a month, about 30 times a year. Similar kilns across the county fire an average of 10-15 times a year. Our process is community driven as well. During the 24 hour firing process, all individuals who purchase a share in the kiln are also encouraged to sign up for a shift throughout the firing. They also assist with the loading and unloading – really making it a community effort.

Groups from the region, hailing from all over Maryland, DC, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Virginia and West Virginia, take advantage of the different techniques and effects that come out of the kiln that are far different than what many get from gas and electric. The kiln is used as a learning tool for ceramic programs in the area; Clayworks sees groups from the Maryland Institute College of Art, Coppin State, CCBC Essex, Morgan University and Towson University to name a few.

There is a great interest and need in the area to have a kiln and facilities like Clayworks in Baltimore. In the past, we’ve raised funds through a similar platform to rebuild our other kilns, had a successful 35th anniversary campaign last year through indiegogo among other targeted project efforts that were successful. Please consider making a gift through this Indiegogo campaign in order for Clayworks to reach our goal for the rebuild.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge during this time is raising the funds to complete the project. We will not be able to move forward with the rebuild unless ALL funds are raised.

We currently have a budget, plans and specs in place for the rebuild. Due to the kiln being outside, we run the obvious risk of weather prohibiting the progress of the build and keeping on track for completing in August.

With vendors and contractors already in place, we are confident that all materials and supplies will be available and our contractor is able to be onsite during the project build.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re looking to help beyond making a contribution, please consider sharing this project to your networks – share on social media, send in an email, or just spread the info about the campaign through good ol’ word of mouth.

Thank you!
story_txt:
Rebuild
the Wood Kiln @ Baltimore Clayworks
Baltimore Clayworks’ mission is to develop, promote and sustain an
artist-centered community, which provides outstanding artistic, educational and
collaborative programs in the ceramic arts. 
Founded in 1980 by a group of nine community-minded ceramic artists,
Baltimore Clayworks has developed a strong local and global reputation for
artists’ development coupled with sustained community engagement.  
Now approaching its 36th year, Clayworks continues to grow, evolve and connect deeply with Baltimore
city and community. Baltimore Clayworks brings the most talented national and
international ceramic artists to both our campus in Mt. Washington and our
community sites in under-resourced neighborhoods across the region. Through
classes, workshops, lectures, events and exhibitions, Clayworks reaches youth,
adults, families and seniors regardless of their social or economic status, by providing
high-quality ceramic arts instruction for the betterment of all.
Each
year Baltimore Clayworks has 12 artists in residence, 4 visiting artists and
20-25 exhibitions in our galleries in Mt. Washington. Clayworks has over 60
professional teaching artists and nearly 400 additional exhibiting artists
throughout the year. Annually we teach over 1,500 students in our studios in
Mt. Washington and over 3,000 students through our Community Arts programs
throughout the City and surrounding area. 
Baltimore
Clayworks is committed to making the arts accessible to those who otherwise
would have limited or no access, bringing professional ceramic artists to
Baltimore to work with youth and senior adults at our satellite studios and in
other spaces in their own communities. By partnering with organizations already
imbedded in the life of the neighborhoods and developing art-making programs
that meet the interests of the community, Baltimore Clayworks has successfully
worked with broad and diverse groups of residents in Baltimore for over three
decades.
This
rings true for our community wood fire program. We offer community members the ability to fire most unique and offerings at Baltimore
Clayworks - the opportunity to fire in our 2 chambered wood burning Noborigama
kiln. With its final firing in May, we now need the community to support the
rebuild the kiln this summer in order to continue firings as early as August!
What
We Need & What You Get
As one of the most publicly used
wood kilns in the area, and across the county, Clayworks is passionate about
the opportunity to provide the wood firing opportunity to the surrounding community. The rebuild
of the kiln will cost $25,000. With the support of one of our generous students, Suzan
Rouse on behalf of the the Awalt Family Foundation, we have $10,000 to put toward the
project – now we just need the remaining $15,000 to get it started! This is
where you come in to help. Over the next 30 days, we will raise these funds
through this online platform. NEW NEWS! Thanks to Dwight and Kirsten Johnson for donating $1,000 to the campaign! Also, thanks to our trustee, James Turnbull; he helped us secure a 100% in-kind donation of bricks from RESCO for the rebuild. 
The total $25,000 will fund an
expert at rebuilding this type of kiln from Kentucky. He will be with us making
plans, executing and building on-site during the process. Funds will also
support materials and supplies, which include items such as: Concrete Block,
Fire Bricks, Fire Insulation, Coarse Grog, Clay, Sand, and Cement. It also
includes tool rentals, labor and instruction.
At each level of giving, you will
receive fantastic perks, ranging from $10 (anyone can do this, right!) all the way up to $25,000, which would cover the entire project and get you naming rights to this beautiful new kiln!At the $25 'Helping Hand' level, snag a ceramic pin/magnet that you can display or wear to show your support of Clayworks and this project. Or, if you give $25,000, this would cover the expenses of the entire project, plus allow for funding to be set aside to cover future materials, supplies, repairs and help with our wood kiln manager's salary. Naming rights of the kiln would be the biggest perk and would provide the $25,000 donor the opportunity to have signage at the kiln and throughout our facilities and other promotions.This

to reach our goal for the rebuild.

story:
The creative work of Laija Laura Ozolina is extraordinary. While gazing at the starry sky, she, too, ponders the blue planet of her own soul. This is the world from which the characters for her unusual works all hail.

It is also where her new project comes from, "The Wonder Maker’s Tale", an illustrated storybook that lets her reveal to you her talents as a writer and painter.​

The book tells ten stories that explore the lives of people who have lived on our planet in various times and cultures.

Each story is illustrated with a painting dedicated to its main hero.

The stories trace past events as they impact both the present and the future through each successive generation, inviting readers to see how from the very moment of our births, each one of us takes part in the creation not only of our own history, but also that of those who will follow us.

These seemingly unrelated events all have a common theme—the soul and its revelation of each person’s life mission.

In her artworks Laija layers sheens of luminescent paint, having developed a unique technique of her own. The paintings surprise their audience with their interchanging hidden images and hues; as the lighting of a particular painting shifts, thousands of new shades glimmer, glow and fade, altering the viewers’ perception of the artwork.

We invite you to participate in the creation of the English version of "The Wonder Maker’s Tale" by contributing towards covering its translation and editing costs from Latvian into English. 

The funds shall be used according to the plan below:

  • Translation of nine stories: ~60%
  • Proofreading, editing and various administrative costs: ~20%
  • Delivery of perks to our valued supporters: ~20%

The stories are 20 to 40 standard pages in length. Each story has to be carefully edited for accuracy and readability, proofread and spellchecked multiple times.
 

Here’s an advance excerpt from one of the stories, "Heavenly": 

Share “The Wonder Maker’s Tale”

If you enjoyed the story excerpt and artwork, please consider helping us complete our project by sharing:

In gratitude for your support, we offer you the complete story "Aziza’s Dream".


 

We have launched the Laija Art brand to better promote our creative collaborations.

"The Wonder Maker’s Tale" currently is our main project.

 

Laija Laura Ozoliņa
Writer, painter and designer, co-founder of Laija Art

Laija has been a continuous creative force of our team, and an inspiration to us all.

“I have always desired to create something beautiful and unusual, like no one else! I believe that anyone who works with the soul can be a wonder maker. With my artwork I want to show it to the world!”

 

Baiba Bicāne
Director and co-founder of Laija Art

Baiba and Laija are an unbreakable tandem, with Baiba being the driving force behind our team’s success.

“Laija Art is like a child to me—one must devote time and patience to her. And, like any child, Laija Art inspires me, gives me joy and the sense that with every new creation, the world becomes a better and more beautiful place.”

 

Zane Broka
Editor-in-Chief

“In a written story, language is the only tool for bringing author’s ideas and images to the reader. My priority is to ensure that each word and every sentence of the Wonder Maker’s Tale when translated from Latvian into English carries along the original message of the author.”

 

Much of the Laija Art portfolio of works can be viewed on our Facebook page:

The video below will introduce you to the creative work of Laija.

 

"The Wonder Maker’s Tale" promises to take new shape as the illustrated book grows into an ambitious stage performance project, combining formats across the fields of visual art, prose fiction, music and dance, audiobooks and film animation.

Composers Lolita Ritmanis (USA) and Aigars Grāvers (Latvia) have already composed special music meant to accompany Laija’s stories and paintings.

When the final editing is done and all of our dear supporters’ perks have been delivered, we will proceed with the release of the book.
 

As a thank-you to our supporters, we have prepared a list of inspirational rewards to choose from.

Heavenly (story & music)

For your contribution you will receive a digital copy of the story "Heavenly" (44 pages, pdf) along with the accompanying music (5 min, mp3) composed by Lolita Ritmanis. The story is available in English, Latvian and Russian.

Please sample an excerpt from the story in English here:


 

The Wonder Maker’s Tale

Upon project completion, you will receive a digital copy of the book "The Wonder Maker’s Tale" along with the accompanying music by Lolita Ritmanis.

The Wonder Maker’s Bow Tie

For your contribution you will receive a unique bow tie hand-painted by Laija and encrusted in Swarovski crystals. Please choose your bow tie from the photos below. Only two Wonder Maker’s Bow Ties are available as a reward.

Sponsors will also receive a copy of "The Wonder Maker’s Tale" upon project completion, along with the accompanying music.
 

The Wonder Maker’s Necktie

For your contribution you will receive a unique silk necktie hand-painted by Laija. Please choose your necktie from the photos below. Only three Wonder Maker’s Neckties are available as a reward.

Supporters will also receive the ebook "The Wonder Maker’s Tale" upon completion, with accompanying music.
 

Wall Art My Fairy Tale (small)

Receive a small canvas print (25W x 30L x 2H cm / 9.8W x 11.8L x 0.8H in) of one of the book illustrations of your choice, signed by the author.

You may choose from the images at the end. Upon the end of the funding period, we will contact you to clarify your choice of image.

You will also receive the electronic version of the book upon project completion along with the accompanying music.

Wall Art My Fairy Tale (medium)

Includes everything listed under Wall Art My Fairy Tale (small), but on a canvas print sized 50W x 60L x 2H cm / 19.7W x 23.6L x 0.8H in.

Wall Art My Fairy Tale (large)

Includes everything listed under Wall Art My Fairy Tale (small), but on a canvas print sized 100W x 120L x 2H cm / 39.4W x 47.2L x 0.8H in.

Sibrona (original UV painting)

You will receive the original luminescent painting "Sibrona" by Laija, as well as the ebook "The Wonder Maker’s Tale" upon completion, with accompanying music by Lolita Ritmanis.

"Sibrona" was created in 2014, on canvas using acrylic and luminescent paints. The artwork has a painted wooden frame; painting size (incl. frame) is 62.5 х 47.5 cm (24.6 x 18.7 in).

When exposed to UV light, the painting changes colors and radiates light as shown in the photos below. The colors will be more vivid when seen in person. UV lamp is not included.


Sibrona (daylight) 


Sibrona (UV light)
 


Turquoise Waves Bow Tie
encrusted in blue Swarovski crystals

 

Shamrock Green Bow Tie
​encrusted in clear white Swarovski crystals

 


Red Coral Necktie


Raspberry Twist Necktie
encrusted in red Swarovski crystals

 

Fairy Forest Necktie
encrusted in blue Swarovski crystals

 

For the canvas wall art prints, we use high resolution professional photos of original paintings. The paintings have been photographed at daylight and at UV light to reveal different images and colors as shown in the photos below. The printed wall art does not have the luminescence effect.


Acceleration (daylight)


Acceleration (UV light)


Born for the Second Time (daylight)


Born for the Second Time (UV light)


Heavenly (daylight)


 

Heavenly (UV light)





 

Leo the Monk (daylight)




 

Leo the Monk (UV light)



 

Niri (daylight)


Niri (UV light)


The Sold Soul (daylight)


Taiga (daylight)


Taiga (UV light)


 

The Dreamer (daylight)


 

The Dreamer (UV light)


 

The Soul of John Fravel (daylight)


 

The Soul of John Fravel (UV light)


The Wonder Maker's Tale (daylight)


The Wonder Maker's Tale (UV light)


White Princess (daylight)


White Princess (UV light)

Note. All perks will be shipped from Latvia (EU). Please keep in mind that should any import taxes be applicable, these will be the responsibility of the contributor.

story:
Artists Background

Akeelah Bertram is an award winning artist who has exhibited nationally and internationally. Her innovative experiments with light and sound have led to the creation of unique immersive experiences for audiences of all ages and backgrounds. Ultiverse builds on her recent work ‘71000’ which debuted at the Royal College of Art this year.

Ultiverse

Ultiverse is an audio visual installation forming an alternate dimension out of light and sound. This immersive installation of refracted light, synthesised audio and a vibration platform experiments with light and sound art. Created by visual artist Akeelah Bertram, Ultiverse will serve as a space for live performance and collaboration throughout October 2016.

Ultiverse installation still 

East Street Arts have generously agreed to support the project as a hosting partner; providing space, staff time and marketing support (amounting to £6,300). Last week our Arts Council application was accepted, which means many technical aspects of the installation are now possible. Unfortunately this funding cannot be used to cover the soft flooring which is required to make this work truly intergalactic, and this is where you come in!

East Street Arts, Patrick Studios

Ultiverse Indiegogo campaign will raise funds for the flooring of the installation. The full £1000 will be spent to transform the 80sqm floor into a soft, reflective surface. The white soft play tiles purchased will also have a life after the project in future installations of the Ultiverse.

This integral part of the work will greatly affect viewers experience of the immersive installation. Raising these funds will enable the installation to be created to the best standard possible

Something for you

Your donation gives you access to some very exclusive perks, in the form of limited edition prints by Akeelah Bertram not yet available for sale! These beautiful photographs capture an intricate light refraction from her previous work Vase, and a stunning visual of Converger - an object from the Ultiverse.

If the goal is not achieved, funds raised will still be used to amend the floor, but to a less effective quality.

Fragment, Chroma Print, 2013 from the installation Vase, 2013

 

Converger, Chroma Print, 2015 from the installation Ultiverse

 

Other ways you can help

Thank you so much for taking an interest in the project, if you're unable to help this time round please spread the word to friends who may be interested using the Indiegogo share tools

See you in the Ultiverse!
