story:
WHO:
Hi there, I’m Madeleine Dietrich. If you’re reading this, you probably know me. If you’ve found this through some other means, great! I am a multimedia artist working in Brooklyn, New York. I have lived in NYC for 7 years and have always considered art an integral part of my life. This year, I am graduating from FIT with my BFA.



WHAT:
My thesis project, which has been in process for over a year. A series of thirty mixed media prints, coupled with a sound installation. The working title/statement for the piece is as follows:

UNLEARN// a study in subverting beauty
It is difficult to imagine a world where one remains free from an enforced standard of beauty. Though this is inescapable in any culture, it seems that within Western culture specifically, we are constantly bombarded with images and advice on how to achieve an unattainable ideal. This installation focuses on a series of individual experiences. It is important to me to include people of all backgrounds, ethnicities, and orientations. I have photographed and interviewed thirty friends and acquaintances - people in my life who I feel subvert the general standard of beauty as it is known today. I have asked each participant about their experience with these standards, and how it has shaped their personal view and definition of beauty.This is a very personal work for me, as I spent years struggling to love and accept my body, unlearning the conventional expectations that are enforced, societally.

Here are a few of the finished works:


WHY:
In order to finish the project, I’ll definitely need some help. As a full-time student with two part-time jobs as well as freelance work, I do not have time to take on any additional work at this time to fund the project. Additionally, as many of you know, I have encountered many financial challenges this year. I have moved five times in the past year due to situations beyond my control (bedbugs, fire, etc.) This, too, resulted in the loss of several security deposits, as well as money I had saved and allocated for the project.

HOW:
Your donations will aid in the completion of my thesis, which will be shown at The Fashion Institute of Technology in May and at a small gallery for emerging artists in July in NYC. Materials needed:
  • Screenprinting materials- chemicals, ink, acetate, lots of expensive paper, paint, pencil, charcoal, etc.
  • Audio- Soundsystem for the audio component (possibly a rental), hard drive.
  • Hanging material- clips, wire, plexiglass.
  • Lighting- LED lights, spotlights for the show
  • Additional materials for printing a book for the show

Thanks so, so much for your consideration and support! Looking forward to finishing the project and seeing you all at the shows! If you can’t donate, please post and share. XOXOXO

story:
Hello everyone!

My name is Erin Skelley, and I am wanting to open up my own online store for my food art-- SkelleyBean Art! I have always wanted to make art for a living, and so I have decided to take my first steps--- but I need your help to make this dream a reality!
The $800 I am hoping to raise are going towards a few things, with the big ticket item being a button maker (usually between $200-300, depending on the size buttons being made). Along with that, I will be using some of the money to buy supplies (LOTS of paper/ sticker paper, pens, brushes, printer ink-- the tools of the trade). Those are the two main things, but a little of this money will also go towards actually setting up my online shops (there are fees to pay to upload things on Etsy, fees to make my website, etc). 
But don't think your patronage will go unnoticed! I have LOTS of cool perks for people that donate towards the cause. Even donating just $1 gets you something, so please check it out and consider donating!
There will be a very special prize for the person that gives the largest donation-- stay tuned on my Facebook page to see what it is!
Don't have the money right now to donate? That's ok! There are still several ways you can help the cause, including:
1. Going to Facebook and liking my art page (which can be found here).
2. Sharing both my Facebook art page AND this fundraising page on Facebook, Tumblr, twitter-- whatever social media platform you want!
3. Letting me know that you believe in the project! Post on my Facebook wall!
I know lots of people dream about making art their living, but with your help, I can be one of the few whose dream could be real! 
Thanks so much for considering donating-- and PLEASE tell your friends! Share on Facebook, Tumblr, even email it to friends-- it would be SO VERY appreciated!

story:
I am a local Washington, DC artist living in the Brookland Neighborhood of Washington and make my living as a sculptor and public artist. My Studio is #11 at the Arts Walk on Monroe Street Market.

I am asking for your help to support fabrication of a permanent piece of public to be placed at the corner of 12th and Rhode Island Avenue NE--the Southern Gateway to Brookland's 12th Street Commercial Corridor. The artwork consists two four foot by nine feet Scarlet Oak Leaves and Acorns placed either side of the Welcome to Brookland Sign.

The Scarlet Oak is the State Tree of Washington, DC.  On the acorns are squirrels, crows and cardinals. Squirrels and crows are the animals that spread the acorns to become seedlings but also use them as their main food source. The cardinals represent nearby Catholic University. Made out of metal and protected with an anti-graffiti clear coat the sculptures will be painted a brightred like Scarlet Oak Leaves during the fall as well as a silvery color to match the aluminum on the Welcome sign.

Illustrate My Design in Alexandria, Virginia has done some wonderful renderings of the artwork and inserted them into site photos.  There are also colored sketches that I have done of the sculpture as well as the cad presentation drawings that designer colleague Brandon Bailey has done for the project.

This money will be used for the sculpture fabrication, transportation costs to move the sculpture from the fabrication shop to the site where it will be installed, painting of the sculpture with a durable paint and primer as well as an anti-graffiti clear coat, structural design of the footings and the attachment brackets for the sculptures, concrete and footing costs, labor and a crane to install the sculptures as well as money for stainless steel plaques.

Lighting of the artwork will be provided through other means.

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Post the campaign on social media, email it to your friends and tweet about it.
  • The Indiegogo share tools will allow you to do this easily.

story:
Thankyou! This campaign is over but the project continues!

Dear friends and supporters,

Our Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign has now come to an end. Thank you to everyone who made a donation, no matter how large or small. We promise to keep our end of the bargain, and as well as announcing a venue for the installation over the next few weeks we’ll also be sending out the promised perks to those who asked for them once the project is fully up and running. As well as the kind and generous crowdfunding donations we’ve received, we’ve also been showered with financial contributions from other sources including cheques sent in the post and direct bank transfers. The campaign to raise money is still open, and as well as writing cheques and making bank transfers you can also donate directly to our NGO PayPal account or make a contribution through our partner in the United States. And don’t forget to subscribe to our newsletter, which we’ll be sending out on a monthly basis to keep you informed about The Kaunas Requiem and our other projects in general.

Thank you again for helping keep Litvak history in the picture.

Richard.

Read the story and find out how to donate below.

The Family

In Between 1941 and 1944 around 95 percent of Lithuania’s pre-war Litvak (Lithuanian Jewish) population of over 200,000 men, women and children were murdered by the Nazis and Lithuanian collaborators during the Holocaust.

In 2013, we uncovered an extraordinary collection of 111 family photographs that had been smuggled out of the Kaunas Ghetto into the hands of sympathetic local Lithuanians. See the photographs here: facebook.com/litvakphoto

Creating a musical memorial

Together with the photographs, we found fascinating evidence of musical performances and show-business activities. Using this as inspiration, we started to plan a fitting memorial for the family, combining the photos with a specially commissioned piece of music and a Reading of the Names. But first we had to find out their names...

Finding the family

We didn't know where to start, so we appealed to you for help. Soon after we launched the appeal, we received many messages of support, and exciting things began to happen. Shelly Tandy Johnson kindly sent us a photograph of her grandmother and grandfather’s sister sitting in the same ‘aeroplane’ that’s featured in one of the photographs in our collection. Read more about her story here: facebook.com/litvakphoto

However, the name of the family in the photographs still eluded us. One of the only clues we had was the name of the small Lithuanian town Birštonas, scribbled on the back of a photograph of a young girl, so we started there.

Finally, with the hard work and help of researcher Saulė Valiūnaitė we have miraculously managed to identify the family and learn much more about their story. It seems the family ran a sanatorium in Birštonas, and there are a lot of records related to them over a period of many years. Tragically, we have also confirmed that they perished, along with so many of their fellow Litvaks, in the Holocaust in Lithuania.

UPDATE: An incredible breakthrough

Amazing news! We have managed to contact living relatives of the family in the photographs! Read more about the latest developments in this interview with our Director, Richard Schofield.

Mystery pre-Holocaust photo trove turns out to be of family of US scholars

You can also read in Yiddish here: סוד אַנטפּלעקט וועגן קאָוונער פֿאָטאָגראַפֿיעס

The Kaunas Requiem. A musical memorial for a Litvak family.

In order to commemorate this lost Litvak family and all Lithuania’s Holocaust victims, we’re creating The Kaunas Requiem, a musical composition lasting 75 years if played in its entirety. A short extract will be performed over a seven-day period to mark the 75th anniversary of the establishment of the Kaunas Ghetto. It will close with a live Reading of the Names event on Lithuanian Holocaust Remembrance Day, September 23, 2016.

The music will be created electronically, converting the names of Kaunas Holocaust victims into sounds. The performance will be accompanied by projections of the photographs that inspired the project. The installation will be simultaneously broadcast online.

You can get an exclusive signed CD of this performance by donating €35!

Who are we?

The International Centre for Litvak Photography is an independent organisation that uses photography as the catalyst for a wide range of educational and cultural events. We aim to put Lithuanian Jewish history back in the picture and create a better understanding of Lithuania’s diverse Litvak cultural heritage.


Anton Degtiariov and Richard Schofield 

Composer Anton Degtiariov graduated from Kiev Music Academy and has completed many experimental musical projects and performances in his native Ukraine. He will work with Lithuanian programmer Rokas Anisas who will teach a computer how to ‘perform’ the Requiem.

Richard Schofield has been living and working in Lithuania for 15 years, receiving a Sugihara Foundation Citizen of Tolerance Award nomination in 2014 for his work protecting Litvak heritage and memory. He founded the International Centre for Litvak Photography as a way to reinvigorate heritage studies and engage the younger generation of Lithuanians.

The project will be helped by members of the International Centre for Litvak Photography’s Advisory Group, including the Litvak writer and activist Sergey Kanovich and the Lithuanian Holocaust historian Milda Jakulytė.

What We Need

We need your donations to make this memorial really special, and to spread the message as far as possible.

We need many man-hours for our experienced professionals to compose and arrange the music, and a lot of equipment to project the photographs and broadcast the resulting video online. Your donations will be split between creators, equipment, logistics, communication costs and administration. We will provide all donors with a full breakdown of how we spent the money.

If we hit the target, the project will be completed and your donations will have a lasting impact on the local Kaunas community. We hope you will help us to raise more than double the target, because if we receive €15,000 or more we will be able to take the performance on tour beyond Kaunas. We plan to visit many forgotten shtetls of the historical Litvak lands, engaging and educating the contemporary population and promoting reconciliation with history.

How to donate

501c3 donations in the USA

Thanks to the kindness of our 501c3 partners The International Lithuanian Federation, you can now make tax deductible donations to us in the USA. Please email us at donate@litvakphoto.org to make the necessary arrangements.

We need your support to make it happen - so please chip in and share!

Paypal: donate@litvakphoto.org

You can donate by Paypal or debit/credit card (choose Guest Checkout option). Guest Checkout works only for donations up to 500$. If you'd like to donate more, simply register a Paypal account. You can also send us a cheque or make an international transfer at:
VšĮ Tarptautinis Litvakų Fotografijos Centras
Vilniaus 10b-2, LT-44280 Kaunas Lithuania
IBAN: LT927044060008029945
SWIFT: CBVILT2X
List of correspondent banks
In case you'll need more information, please send an email to:
info@litvakphoto.org

However, the name of the family in the photographs still eluded us. One of the only clues we had was the name of the small Lithuanian town Birštonas, scribbled on the back of a photograph of a young girl, so we started there.


Finally, with the hard work and help of researcher Saulė Valiūnaitė we have miraculously managed to identify the family and learn much more about their story. It seems the family ran a sanatorium in Birštonas, and there are a lot of records related to them over a period of many years. Tragically, we have also confirmed that they perished, along with so many of their fellow Litvaks, in the Holocaust in Lithuania.
UPDATE: An incredible breakthrough
Amazing news! We have managed to contact living relatives of the family in the photographs! Read more about the latest developments in this interview with our Director, Richard Schofield.
Mystery pre-Holocaust photo trove turns out to be of family of US scholars
You can also read in Yiddish here: סוד אַנטפּלעקט וועגן קאָוונער פֿאָטאָגראַפֿיעס



The Kaunas Requiem. A musical memorial for a Litvak family.
In order to commemorate this lost Litvak family and all Lithuania’s Holocaust victims, we’re
creating The Kaunas Requiem, a musical
composition lasting 75 years if played in its entirety. A short extract will be
performed over a seven-day period to mark the 75th anniversary of the
establishment of the Kaunas Ghetto. It will close with a live Reading of the
Names event on Lithuanian Holocaust Remembrance Day, September 23, 2016. 
The music will be created electronically,
converting the names of Kaunas Holocaust victims into sounds. The performance
will be accompanied by projections of the photographs that inspired the
project. The installation will be simultaneously broadcast online.
You can get an exclusive signed CD of this
performance by donating €35!


Who are we?





The International Centre for Litvak Photography is an independent organisation that uses photography as the catalyst for a wide range of educational and cultural events. We aim to put Lithuanian Jewish history back in the picture and create a better understanding of Lithuania’s diverse Litvak cultural heritage.




Anton Degtiariov and Richard Schofield 

Composer Anton Degtiariov graduated from Kiev Music Academy and has completed many experimental musical projects and performances in his native Ukraine. He will work with Lithuanian programmer Rokas Anisas who will teach a computer how to ‘perform’ the Requiem.
Richard Schofield has been living and working in Lithuania for 15 years, receiving a Sugihara Foundation Citizen of Tolerance Award nomination in 2014 for his work protecting Litvak heritage and memory. He founded the International Centre for Litvak Photography as a way to reinvigorate heritage studies and engage the younger generation of Lithuanians.
The project will be helped by members of the International Centre for Litvak Photography’s Advisory Group, including the Litvak writer and activist Sergey Kanovich and the Lithuanian Holocaust historian Milda Jakulytė.


What We Need
 
We need your donations to make this memorial really special, and to spread the message as far as possible.
We need many man-hours for our experienced professionals to compose and arrange the music, and a lot of equipment to project the photographs and broadcast the resulting video online. Your donations will be split between creators, equipment, logistics, communication costs and administration. We will provide all donors with a full breakdown of how we spent the money.
If we hit the target, the project will be completed and your donations will have a lasting impact on the local Kaunas community. We hope you will help us to raise more than double the target, because if we receive €15,000 or more we will be able to take the performance on tour beyond Kaunas. We plan to visit many forgotten shtetls of the historical Litvak lands, engaging and educating the contemporary population and promoting reconciliation with history.


How to donate

501c3 donations in the USA
Thanks to the kindness of our 501c3 partners The International Lithuanian Federation, you can now make tax deductible donations to us in the USA. Please email us at donate@litvakphoto.org to make the necessary arrangements.We need your support to make it happen - so please chip in and share!Paypal: donate@litvakphoto.orgYou can donate by Paypal or debit/credit card (choose Guest Checkout option). Guest Checkout works only for donations up to 500$. If you'd like to donate more, simply register a Paypal account. You can also send us a cheque or make an international transfer at:VšĮ Tarptautinis Litvakų Fotografijos CentrasVilniaus 10b-2, LT-44280 Kaunas Lithuania IBAN: LT927044060008029945 SWIFT: CBVILT2XList of correspondent banksIn case you'll need more information, please send an email to:info@litvakphoto.org

story:
Arctic Circle Residency

I have been accepted to The Arctic Circle artist residency for June of 2016. During the residency I will spend two weeks on an ice-class sailing ship at the Arctic Circle together with a group of other artists and scientists. I will use my time in the Arctic to research and gather images for a new body of artworks.

As an artist I often work with landscape imagery, and I engage with environmental issues in my work. The Arctic landscape seems like an ideal fit for my concerns, given its natural beauty and susceptibility to the ravages of Global Climate Change.

The sailing trip to the Arctic Circle is a once in a lifetime opportunity to see this fragile area in person. I will also meet and share research with an international group of artists and scientists. The impact on my art will be immense.

Information about the residency may be found here:

http://www.thearcticcircle.org/

Funding Required

  • Residency Fee: $6300
  • Flight to Svalbard, Norway: $1900

Perks & Thank You Gifts

In exchange for your support I will send you works of art. The selection of art will depend on the level of support, ranging from $5 - $1000.

In most cases the value of the art will be approximately equal to the amount of support donated. So really you are just buying art, with the added perk of knowing you are supporting my expedition.

You can view the art thank you gifts in the gallery on this site.

To see more of my work visit:

http://www.rbarlow.net/

Risks & Challenges

  • I am committed to going on this trip, so any contributions will be used and will help offset any debt I will need to take on.
  • I have already secured $2000 in grant funding, offsetting some of these expenses.

  • And polar bears. Polar bears are a risk.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, but would still like to help me reach my goal, please spread the word about this campaign to anyone who would be interested!


(ship photo courtesy of The Arctic Circle)

story:
In Short

CHROMA is a collaborative installation of photographs and performance art based in the healing modalities of chakra alignment and color psychology. It will explore, individually, each color of the chakras. CHROMA is a black-led project created by Anicka Austin and Crystal Monds, both active artists and yogini healers in Atlanta, GA.

Art As Healing
Using colors for healing, with a focused artist’s eye can bridge the gap between art, healing justice, and spiritual maintenance. As healers, we continue to research color healing & psychology, and explore how we can harness our ancestral power to promote emotional and spiritual wellness. Because color is necessary and ancestrally, color has been used for healing since human consciousness, we can intentionally use it to positively enhance lives. 


Why You Wanna Make This Happen

  • You can get bragging rights to having funded independent artists!
  • We have an incredibly diverse cast.
  • This is a Black woman led project in the South where it is extremely important for us to tell our own stories, make our own noise, honor our expressions, and create our own visibility.
  • The community effort and involvement in creating this work furthers relationships in the arts and in healing communities in Atlanta.
  • We're making sure to keep the experience as inclusive & borderless as possible. This means we need more funds upfront to make the work more accessible down the road to folks with less resources.

Where the Contributions Go

$10,000 will help us pay for:

  • Dancers/Production Team Compensation
  • Design-stage, environment building, seating, lighting
  • Costumes, Styling
  • Photographic printing, Lighting
  • Promotional materials 
  • Travel, Location

    We've prioritized paying our dancers and team for their work and paying for photographic printing first. It's super important that we care for our artists and bring you great work! If we don't make our goal, the final experience will only be slightly less amazing, but don't you want all the bells & whistles?

The Impact

  • This project is valuable because self-care is important. Introducing new ways to use color in your self-care practices can add value to your everyday experiences and put some more knowledge in your bag.
    Be prepared to pay it forward. It's widely known that when you're in good emotional health, people around you will feel it too!

Artists' Backgrounds
For more info on some of our previous works, check out our websites!
Crystal Monds Photography Website
Esoteric Lore Photography Collective
Anicka Austin Website


Why Is This Such A Big Deal?

CHROMA is a year-long project with an amazingly talented cast of 9 performing artists, and with such an ambitious project comes many welcome challenges. Among them are the extensive hours of rehearsal to create 7 full-length works, acquiring rights to music, and ensuring that we have the proper dance floors for our performers. More things to consider are photographic equipment, printing large-scale photographs for 7 full shows, and transforming the exhibit spaces into multiple color saturated rooms while keeping full integrity of the photographs on display. 

This is a truly collaborative and multi-sensory experience. We aren't just making one show or installing one exhibit. Our Spring iteration will be 3 days long and our Fall iteration will span a full month.


We have a team of supporters helping us with components of the work that require other forms of expertise.

Other Ways To Help

  • Tell ya mama! Tell ya friends!

    Really, though. If you can't contribute financially, please do make a lot of noise. Use our hashtags #oodcchroma and #chroma16 to keep this project visible with the Indiegogo share tools and anywhere you are on social media.
    Thank you so much for your support!

story:
We've got lights, sound, and fire!

StarDust is a custom built art car that made its on playa debut at Burning Man 2014.  The exoskeleton of StarDust rotates independently from the base vehicle delivering a continually changing 360 degree view of the passing scenery.  The disorienting visual sensation challenges the rider to experience the sights and sounds of Black Rock city with whole new perspective.

Since September 2014 we have overhauled the electrical/lighting system, gave StarDust a shiny new paint job and completed much need mechanical maintenance on the quad.  We like to share that burner love and wonderment with our local community too.  In May StarDust participated at the San Mateo Makers Faire and Meet the Machines, giving children of all ages have the opportunity to touch, climb on and explore alternative transportation methods.

Next stop is the burn in Black Rock City NV help us bring the Star to the playa to keep the city moving!

What We Need & What You Get

I'm ask for your assistance to raise $650 to off set transportation, operation and fabrication costs.  The end result is for ME to help burners like YOU to get from point A to point B.

  • $250 - fabrication materials to  pacify the DMV and 'disguise' the quad
  • $100 - transportation to Black Rock City 
  • $160 - propane for flame effects
  • $60 - trailer jack
  • $80 - metal stock for ramps 

The one piece of feedback I received from the Department of Muntant Vehicles last year was they could still see the base vehicle a blue Yamaha Kodiak.   We squeaked though by driving back to camp, duck taping a bed sheet over the quad and returned for a re inspection with a bottle of Jack.  This year I'd like to fabricate a ying-yang over the center of the quad to obscure it completely from view.

Did You Know?

Black Rock City 5 miles across and has more than 60 miles of roads. Last year there were more than 250 art installations scatter throughout the open playa.

Worried you won't be able to see it all? 

StarDust provides community interaction - for everyone.  You won't find VIP wrist bands or private parties here.  I don't care if its your 1st burn or your 20th burn.  If there is an open seat and we are pointed (haha - get it? points) in the right direction let's go!  You don't need a Mistress of Merriment to ride this art car, in fact you don't even need pants.  Whether your trying to get to artica, the airport, or that  crazy cool armadillo installation by the trash fence you heard about, that is what StarDust is here for:  making playa adventures come true.    

Thank you!

For each donation of $25 or above we will send you a classy SuperStar Bottle Opener (colors may vary).

story:
The Pursuit of Artsy-ness

Some Backstory

My name is Quinton Counts, and I am a performer, curator, and community advocate in NYC. I remember that back since I was a kid, I use to have this thing where I was really closed up. And it didn't help that I was going through a lot. Rap helped to get me out of my shell socially, then I started coming across these other crafts and organizing in my neighborhood in Harlem. Seeing the impact that in peoples lives made me see that "hey, maybe I should stick to this". With my background in civic work, in the workforce, and in art, I saw an intrinsic connection between these areas. 

I strongly believe that local businesses can collaborate with artists in a way that betters the community and the economy. There is a way to create a platform to connect with social innovators and people who are in the academic world.. I like to use art and events to find ways to do that. 

If there's one thing we can all agree on, it's that art either influences society, or it reflects it. At this point, it's easy to not think about it consciously, because it's always been there. It's why corporations spend so much money on marketing and advertisement, which art is an innate part of. So, whether you are a person who is looking to be an artist as your main career, something you do on the side, or something you don't mind simply witnessing, it's something that affects peoples lives.

As of late, I've been hosting engaging events, forum discussions, connecting people with social innovators, incorporating live performances, capturing event footage and presenting them in a cool way. I will also be filming a dancer doing a dance piece in a cinematography bit (and maybe incorporate a vocal artist). I would be interviewing that dancer about how she excelled as a dancer when people told her she couldn't. I'd then host that interview on my site.  


Why I Need Your Help


I need some equipment to help operationally. Things are simply easier when you have your own equipment and don't have to always refer to a third party. Plus I'll be able to train people in event planning. photo/video/audio editing, using a camera, etc. I already routinely put every dollar that I have into these things, but this will really help me get a major step up. 

I'm open to feedback or general conversation about any of these topics, I'm more than open to discuss possible collaboration, and any funds donated are highly appreciated

Wanna see? www.WolfSetProductions.com



Perks, Perks, and Perks!

Look, you work hard for your money, you have bills. I understand, so anything is truly appreciated. But here is some incentives I was able to work out for those who donate

$1 and up - I'll give you two mixtapes. One will have one of my own mixtapes, and the other will have some of my favorite music that was made by my friends

up to $50 - I'll send you a framed picture with a visual work that was done or by one of my really talented visual artist friend

$100 and up - I'll send the music, the picture, and a WolfSet tee (just send me your size)

Of course I'll update the perks as I come up with other ideas and gain resources.

All of these packages will include information about some of the startups and organizations that I partner with that I feel are doing great things in this city and beyond.


Thank You

I've worked out what I think is some pretty cool perks to show my appreciation for your help

story:
1...2...3...PAINTBRUSH!

Hi Briarcliff, it's Mr. Maas!
You might recall I taught art at Todd Elementary School from 2003 - 2009.
Being a part of the Briarcliff Manor Community were some of the greatest years of my life. I left Todd in 2009 to follow my dream and in 2012 I truly learned what that was. When Hurricane Sandy struck New York City and the first floor of my Brooklyn Studio building was flooded, I joined the relief effort and worked leading volunteers to clean mold and rebuild homes across NYC. As an artist, I witnessed the colossal impact volunteering has on the quality of life for people who get involved in helping others. I was inspired to start an organization—the Artist Volunteer Center—in 2013, that focuses on helping to connect artists with humanitarian volunteer opportunities, and supports the careers of artists who make a difference. I am following my dream, and I am reaching out to ask that you pitch in to help the cause.

Turning Challenges into Solutions

Funding is scarce for arts non profits, and Jason Maas has managed to do alot with very little. The way he is able to do this is by getting people to work together. You might recall how in the classroom he always met every situation with calm, patient, and positive attitude, and that he could inspire people to get creative and work as hard as they can. He now utilizes these skills to connect individuals, organizations, institutions, and government and the common goal of helping artists help people. 

Every single donation you give supports his work and the work of everyone involved with the Artist Volunteer Center. 

What We Need!

    • We are seeking to raise at least $5,000 to help us fund our existing programs to provide artists with more partnerships, resources, supplies, and a greater network to connect with communities.
    • We are seeking to expand our pop up art show program, by hosting gallery shows centered around socially-conscious themes throughout the city.
    • We want to unveil new programs to help our artists help more people and in turn receive valuable career boosting services like studio space, gallery shows, grants, and curatorial visits.

  • We are seeking contributions to help fund our programming! 

    The work I have done, am currently doing, and am seeking to expand involves:

    • Embedding artists in homeless shelters through long-term volunteer opportunities.
    • Connecting foreign born and first generation Americans with seniors and aging populations in their culture.
    • Connecting teens with internships at food justice and income-inequality organizations.
    • Hosting art shows in galleries around NYC to foster the creation of art from all of these vital endeavors.


What You Get!

    • To show our appreciation for helping us out, we have some great gifts, from stickers, to original artwork by Jason Maas, to tickets to the Artist Volunteer Center fundraiser & art auction held this fall in NYC! Take a look at our perks!

The Impact

  • In just over a year and half of being in existence, the Artist Volunteer Center has impacted over 3000 at-risk and underserved New Yorkers with our programs.
  • We have helped connect over 30 artists with artist-in-residences, provided them with gallery shows, assisted them in securing grants, and employment through our network and our city-wide partnerships.
  • Jason Maas has repeatedly testified before the city council, is a part of several working groups and been awarded grant money to provide the city with ways to ensure equity in the arts for all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you know of anyone who got a chance to be a student in Mr. Maas' classroom who doesn't know about this campaign? Please share it with them! 

There are lots of folks who never got to know Mr. Maas, and the impact he had on you, your family, and your community. Will you take a minute to share this campaign with them and tell them about what Mr. Maas meant to you, and how meaningful the work he is doing now is?

We are seeking to raise at least $5,000 to help us fund our existing programs to provide artists with more partnerships, resources, supplies, and a greater network to connect with communities.
We are seeking to expand our pop up art show program, by hosting gallery shows centered around socially-conscious themes throughout the city.
We want to unveil new programs to help our artists help more people and in turn receive valuable career boosting services like studio space, gallery shows, grants, and curatorial visits.


We are seeking contributions to help fund our programming! 
The work I have done, am currently doing, and am seeking to expand involves:

Embedding artists in homeless shelters through long-term volunteer opportunities.
Connecting foreign born and first generation Americans with seniors and aging populations in their culture.
Connecting teens with internships at food justice and income-inequality organizations.
Hosting art shows in galleries around NYC to foster the creation of art from all of these vital endeavors.




What You Get!


To show our appreciation for helping us out, we have some great gifts, from stickers, to original artwork by Jason Maas, to tickets to the Artist Volunteer Center fundraiser & art auction held this fall in NYC! Take a look at our perks!

The Impact


In just over a year and half of being in existence, the Artist Volunteer Center has impacted over 3000 at-risk and underserved New Yorkers with our programs.
We have helped connect over 30 artists with artist-in-residences, provided them with gallery shows, assisted them in securing grants, and employment through our network and our city-wide partnerships.
Jason Maas has repeatedly testified before the city council, is a part of several working groups and been awarded grant money to provide the city with ways to ensure equity in the arts for all.


    Other Ways You Can Help Do you know of anyone who got a chance to be a student in Mr. Maas' classroom who doesn't know about this campaign? Please share it with them! 
There are lots of folks who never got to know Mr. Maas, and the impact he had on you, your family, and your community. Will you take a minute to share this campaign with them and tell them about what Mr. Maas meant to you, and how meaningful the work he is doing now is?

story:
Inflect Yourself!

We go from place to place, often for the sole purpose of getting there. We work, expend energy and intellect, just to get where we're going. Often we wind close to where we started, yet transformed by the journey. It was the work that mattered, and the experience on the way.

Inflection is a massive, interactive, combustible art piece that we are building for Burning Man 2015. Our generous art grant from BMOrg helped us get the project started, but we need your help to bring it to the playa. We currently need help funding build materials, custom-fabricated components, transport, and decomposed granite. A segment of the installation is also ready for debut at the regional Burn, Critical Northwest.

By contributing to Inflection, you are gifting Black Rock City with a special place to pass muster, play, congregate, and reflect on life's many journeys. Help us materialize our vision at Burning Man this year!

(Footnotes: Combine perk tiers for a customized rewards package! In depth about Inflection below.)


Update 7/30

We are in the process of organizing the perks to be sent out.  We appreciate your patience while we sort through them all!  More to follow on this.  Photos of the perks are being put up on the follow up campaign, so check there to see what's coming!

Thanks much!


Update 7/23

Thank you so much to everyone that has contributed already!   We have launched a follow up campaign that can be seen here: http://igg.me/at/inflection2/x/11521783
And don't forget to come to our fundraiser tomorrow at Re-Bar in Seattle!  The event can be seen here: https://www.facebook.com/events/712212988908486/
Much love for all!  See you in the dust!

Update 7/4

We have an amazing fundraising event coming up in just a few weeks. On 7/24, join us at Re-Bar for WOD and Inflection Present: Bridge Burner!

https://www.facebook.com/events/712212988908486/

This family un-friendly event will feature not so classic Amerikan style picnic games like Pajama Tug-of-War, A Three Legged Dance Off, and a chance to unload your emotional baggage publicly by Burning Bridges with Inflection. Get your tickets early before they sell out!

Our most recent work party was last Thursday. We continued cutting, drilling, and assembling planks for the Bulb sections - check out our progress diagram!

Sections in white are complete, yellow are in progress, and blue have not been started. As you can see we are on schedule and working hard, but we still need your help. We need funds to buy more fabrication materials and to transport this amazing installation to Black Rock City!


Don't forget about our Oscillator perk - rope swings are great!



We will have rope swings and other interactive pieces of Inflection for you to enjoy at our Bridge Burner party. Come out and play with us!

Philosophical statement

We go from place to place, often for the sole purpose of getting there. We work, expend energy and intellect, just to get where we're going. Often we wind up not far form where we were, but transformed by the journey rather than the destination. It was the work that mattered, and the experience on the way.

The journey on the bridge starts easily, and gets more crowded and convoluted across the path. The transformative moment signals the change; traversing the unsettling twist puts one truly on the other side of the journey. At the end, we can view the journey as an accomplishment on its own. It's a solo endeavour, made easier with the help of others on the same path, and done in the midst of those who have made the same journey, and those who may be willing to take it on.

On the way, we fight the elements as well. The bridge, totally suspended save for its endpoints, will move with the exertions of others, and with the wind and elements. It is a small struggle with rewards, pushing ourselves to achieve the goal and overcome the obstacles to come out the other side.

Work must be done. Rewards are reaped with the accomplishment of investment.


Project description

The bridge structure itself is fully suspended from tall 6x6 masts, which loom high above. The mouths of the bridge are anchored tightly to the ground. The bridge itself, composed of suspended planks of wood (2x4), extends from wide mouths through a wicked S-curve. In the center of the bridge the flat planks perform a half-twist, Mobius-style, on which the traveller must negotiate an edge of the bridgework, using the hanging ropes and hands of her fellows for stability. On crossing the twist, the traveller will find herself truly on the other side of the bridge, where she will complete her journey through the other symmetrical side. The wind may wreak some havoc with the traveller on her journey across as well.

The planks are suspended from the masts by numerous ropes. The juxtaposition of curved contours and linear planks and ropes make for a compelling silhouette. The curves themselves are organic, and provide very differnt shapes from different viewing angles. The ropes are attached to planks with a strong, metal-free design.

The masts are 6x6 posts, buried into the playa and guyed down for stability and safety. The suspension ropes are likely to be attached to steel rings capping the masts. The masts must be strongly coupled at their joins, likely with 2x6 cladding and tongue-in-groove construction. (The original proposal specified curved metal trusswork from which the bridge was suspended, but this has proven costly and the stability was uncertain. The masts are a fine replacement, and burnable to boot.)

Beneath the bridge, most of which is suspended above head-height, is a light garden. Seating around the mast bases and LED lights will feature, where others can gather, take small shelter form the wind, and enjoy the serenity of a transformative achievement. Other artists will have the opportunity to display smaller sculptures below as well. We are also considering artful shade structures for daytime relief, and monitored burn barrels for warmth at night.

Viewed during the day, the bridge presents a visually appealing curved shape composed of straight lines. The twist has a functional purpose as well, that of preventing bikes from recklessly plowing into unsuspecting burners. At night, the bridge is lit with animated LED lights and the garden below. The suspension lines may be lit as well. Guy lines must be lit at their bases.

A small powerhouse is erected to the side, housing a generator providing power to the lights. It is ventilated but otherwise sound-shielded to minimize the noise of the generator. We are also considering a solar-battery component as a nice-to-have, but this much light gets power-hungry. Trenches will conceal power cables in conduit.

story:
Un-Titled Project is an Art/Fashion Magazine with a Coffee Table Book attitude!

Five years ago, UTP was founded by NYC based photographer, and former photo editor of Harper's Bazaar- Dennis Golonka. With the recession in full swing, and outlets for photographers and artists drying up; UTP aspired to bring together  works of art by  established artists, and talented newcomers.  

We have grown through the years and would like to keep on growing, this is why we are asking for your help. 

UTP is run by a  small team of dedicated people, passionate about the worlds of art, fashion, writing and photography: Creative Director: Dennis Golonka, Fashion Director: Romina Herreara Malatesta,  Executive Editor: Thom Lonardo, Contributing Arts Editor: Wayne Northcross, Producer: Matt Brown,  Junior Fashion Editors: Anna Devereux and Page Schultz Contributing Market Editor Giorgia Fuzio, Fashion Assistants Caitlin Cowger, Samantha Chloe Rex and Photo Editor: Leif Harrison. UTP is horizontally bound - measuring  11 x 9 inches. We print using high grade paper for best reproduction.

Issue 8 will be over 250 pages of pure editorial content. Our largest issue to date!  We need your contributions to make this happen.  Some of the artists involved with Issue 8 are:  Yelena Yemchuk, Matthew Jensen, Tim Barber, Paul P, Jock Sturges, Lucas Foglia, Dustin Lance Black, Cory Michael Smith, Tali Lennox, Peter Vack, architects Tham &Videgard,  Daniel Radcliffe, Cody Simpson, Sarah Paulson, Sam Claflin, Venetia Scott,  Malerie Marder,Christophe Kutner, Tim Richmond, Ben Lamberty, Dennis Golonka, Alex Straulino, Yann Faucher and more...

What we need.

The funding goal is $14,750. This will help with the cost associated with Printing, Shipping, and Distribution. 

WHAT YOU GET!

Check out the side bar to view our AMAZING PERKS!  See below for images of our perks being offered!

Whether you pledge, or simply share our link via email and social media, we at UTP THANK YOU!

Feel free to contact us with any questions at - Contact@un-titledproject.com

____________________________________________________________________

AVAILABLE PERK IMAGES:


Paul Mpagi Sepuya ( AVAILABLE PERK )

story:
What's So Great About Reality? is an art exhibition at featuring New York City based artists and curators Jefre Harwoods and Kaitlin Martin. The exhibition at gallery onetwentyeight in the Lower East Side, will open on October 15th and run through November 8th.

Jefre Harwoods will show his latest Headline Collage Poems, the words plucked from the News.

Kaitlin Martin will debut her Google Maps Landscapes, creating myths out of reality.

There will also be scheduled events during the exhibition, including music and performances by guest artists. 

Since 2006, Jefre Harwoods & Kaitlin Martin have together curated and produced a number of successful exhibitions and events at gallery ONETWENTYEIGHT. 

Exhibitions: Something (2012),e = enigma (2011), rEvolution (2010), IT! - Mutants, Hybrids, Combines, Whatever (2008), Escape to Landscape... & Beyond (2007), Where We Are (2006).

Images from past shows

In addition to these exhibitions, Jefre and Kaitlin have created an online exhibition/blog Inside the Museum.

Jefre Harwoods, The Dog of July Eats the Sky, July 22, 2015

Kaitlin Martin, Northern Painting, 2015

onetwentyeight is the longest running gallery in the Lower East Side, run by artist, Kazuko Miyamoto in 1986. 

Please check out the gallery's website: galleryonetwentyeight.org

More work by Jefre and Kaitlin can be seen at these links: jefreharwoods.com, kaitlinmartin.com. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Gallery Rental at ONETWENTYEIGHT $1,800
  • Advertising for show including, Printed Postcards and Web Placement. $600
  • Framing for works on paper. $1,000
  • Administative costs, including a stipend for an intern/assistant and gallery sitters. $1,200  
  • Any money we get above the $4,600 will go towards a limited edition printed catalog of the exhibition, and/or funding for our next project.
If we don't reach our entire goal, the money we make will first go towards renting the space, then framing, advertising, administrative...in that order.

PERKS include limited edition postcards and prints of work from the exhibition, as well as original & unique pieces by Jefre Harwoods & Kaitlin Martin.
Anyone who donates at least $80 will receive a custom t-shirt by Jefre Harwoods and Kaitlin Martin.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still help by getting the word out about our exhibition through email, word of mouth, by sharing through social media and by using the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for contributing and/or helping.

story:
Summary

  • My Name is Lacey Wallace and my mother Bette Anne Wygant is an artist living in Connecticut who hopes to work on an international art project.  It's always been a dream of hers, but I think with your help we can make it happen:
  • Bette Anne's hope is to spend two months in the Middle East painting and exploring the Holy Lands via Beirut, Lebanon which is at the heart of the old and new worlds.  She says, "There is so much energy, potential, and continual evolution and I'd love to paint this moment." 
  • With winds of change and refugees in need of support on one hand, and on the other a culture that is diverse, vibrant, and budding there is much to learn and paint.  Bette Anne says, "I'm so inspired to take it all in as an artist and work in this space, sharing my vision of light and energy through my work. I'm excited for the possibilities to raise awareness of the refugee crisis too.  I'd also like to donate proceeds of a painting done in Lebanon to help the refugees."
  • Upon her return to Connecticut she, "Hopes to collaborate with a local events to raise awareness of the plight refugees & promise of the Lebanese through my paintings." with communities in Connecticut.

What Bette Anne Needs & What You Get

  • We need $6000 to pay for air fair, local travel, lodging, art supplies, shipping, security, local guides, and food for 2 months.
  • Get excited:  Not only will you get a postcard for as little as a 2$ donation and many other perks, but also the first 250 supporters will have a chance to win an original oil painting by BA Wygant called "Harmony" This is a 750$ oil painting you could win for as little as 2$! You can see it here: http://www.bawygant.com/products/harmony-original-oil-painting
  • Other artists have also asked to donate work to support subsequent raffles each time we hit a goal in activity we will kick off the next raffle.  So stay tuned- These wonderful and talented local artists have donated beautiful work to support the project!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will go towards a shorter duration project where Bette Anne will go and support the work of a local UN linked NGO project working with art & empowering local women in Beirut Lebanon.  She will also share her experiences at a local event in Connecticut open to the public with a Q&A session that we will video tape and put online.

The Impact

  • Through Bette Anne's project you are supporting the development of international art initiatives that help bridge distance and culture to form a bond of artistic understanding.
  • Through her art work she will be opening up to new experiences and new visualizations of peace, sisterhood, and brotherhood inspired by the values we all share.  She could not do this without your help.
  • No matter what our background is we can all recognize and explore our perspectives on the world and our place in it through art.
  • You will personally be bringing Bette Anne's artwork to a new stage of evolution through these experiences. 

Risks & Challenges

From Bette Anne, "I know language and cultural barriers are hard to overcome, but with local artists and students as my guides I'm certain I'll be able to connect with Beirut communities through my art.  Artistic expression is the Universal language of the Soul. Painting is a deeply spiritual communication, and I am looking forward to offering my visual prayers for Hope, Peace and Brotherhood. We are ONE, wherever you may call Home."

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially?  That doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help get the word out & make some noise about this campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools so the system can help us make it go viral!

With winds of change and
refugees in need of support on one hand, and on the other a culture that is
diverse, vibrant, and budding there is much to learn and paint.  Bette Anne says, "I'm so inspired to take it all in as an
artist and work in this space, sharing my vision of light and energy through my
work. I'm excited for the possibilities to raise awareness of the refugee crisis too.
 I'd also like to donate proceeds of a painting done in Lebanon to help
the refugees."


Upon her return to Connecticut she, "Hopes to collaborate with a local
events to raise awareness of the plight refugees & promise of the Lebanese through
my paintings." with communities in Connecticut.

   What Bette Anne Needs & What You Get  We need $6000 to pay for air fair, local travel, lodging, art supplies, shipping, security, local guides, and food for 2 months. Get excited:  Not only will you get a postcard for as little as a 2$ donation and many other perks, but also the first 250 supporters will have a chance to win an original oil painting by BA Wygant called "Harmony" This is a 750$ oil painting you could win for as little as 2$! You can see it here: http://www.bawygant.com/products/harmony-original-oil-painting

Other artists have also asked to donate work to support subsequent raffles each time we hit a goal in activity we will kick off the next raffle.  So stay tuned- These wonderful and talented local artists have donated beautiful work to support the project! If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will go towards a shorter duration project where Bette Anne will go and support the work of a local UN linked NGO project working with art & empowering local women in 
Beirut Lebanon.  She will also share her experiences at a local event in Connecticut open to the public with a Q&A session that we will video tape and put online.    The Impact  Through Bette Anne's project you are supporting the development of international art initiatives that help bridge distance and culture to form a bond of artistic understanding.
Through her art work she will be opening up to new experiences and new visualizations of peace, sisterhood, and brotherhood inspired by the values we all share.  She could not do this without your help.
No matter what our background is we can all recognize and explore our perspectives on the world and our place in it through art.
You will personally be bringing Bette Anne's artwork to a new stage of evolution through these experiences.     Risks & Challenges  From Bette Anne, "I know language and cultural barriers are hard to overcome, but with local artists and students as my guides I'm certain I'll be able to connect with Beirut communities through my art.  Artistic expression is the Universal language of the Soul. Painting is a deeply spiritual communication, and I am looking forward to offering my visual prayers for Hope, Peace and Brotherhood. We are ONE, wherever you may call Home."  Other Ways You Can Help Can't contribute financially?  That doesn't mean you can't help:  Help get the word out & make some noise about this campaign. Please use the Indiegogo share tools so the system can help us make it go viral!

story:
Our goal is to raise at least $10,000! This will help us cover the cost of producing the 12-month, 2019 Juneteenth Calendar. See below for interim goals. We'll use what we can raise, but we want to raise more than than our immediate needs, so that we can keep expanding our vision.

About this campaign

This project is about helping me realize my dream to share with everyone the knowledge that has had such a powerful impact on me and my communities, that's inspired and informed my art and my activism. I consider this Juneteenth Calendar, filled with my art and my research, to be my most important contribution to society. It will reach more people and has the potential to inspire others to learn more and do more than anything else I've done.

I'm Isaka Shamsud-Din. I'm 77 and I've been an artist since I was 5 or 6. It's been a long road to get to where I am today, I've encountered many obstacles and many successes and lucky breaks. I am fortunate. Making art has always been at the core of my being. And teaching allows the sharing of my knowledge, technique, and zeal to create. The discoveries and revelations that I experience in my research reward and compel me to dig for more. I'm committed to producing the highest quality art that I can, and to sharing notes and articles about historical and contemporary people and events that have helped shape our world, our society.

I've been doing the research that is feeding into this calendar for more than 50 years. And let me tell you, there was no Wikipedia back when, and few good sources of authoritative information about the lives of black folk. It’s been tedious at times, yet so inspiring. The more I learned, the more I wanted to know, the more I want to share. I want to share my experience with as many people as possible. The Juneteenth Calendar offers a way to do that, and it gives a glimpse into a broader view of how we all got to this chapter of our shared history.

Our goals

If we raise $5,000, that will secure the cost of printing the calendar. Final costs will be in the range of $8,000 - $12,000 (we'll let you know). If we raise it by October 25, we'll open up an exclusive $150 perk: invitation to a LIMITED ATTENDANCE OPEN STUDIO EVENT at my Cathedral Park Place studio in the St Johns neighborhood of Portland.

If we raise $10,000--this is the real deal--it means we can keep on using Indiegogo to raise funds for related programs. We'll be able to establish a non-profit and get the financial services we need to create a solid foundation for ongoing programs related to the calendar, run with transparency and accountability.

If we raise $15,000 before the campaign deadline, every Indiegogo supporter will receive a invitations to a Black History Month block party, a Juneteenth Celebration, and/or any other invitation-only events we dream up, held in conjunction with the Children's Art & Social Justice Council (formerly Don't Shoot Portland) and other sponsors. We'll develop a companion website to the Juneteenth Calendar, where we'll tell more in-depth stories of the people, places, and events featured in the calendar.

If we raise more than $15,000, you know we'll put it to good use!  In fact, if we meet our goal, we plan to keep raising money to sustain the operation of the non-profit and develop curricula and supporting materials to continue this work. We'll work to help un-erase the erasure of the black community in Portland and to use art as a means of social engagement, inclusion, and healing for all people.

Some of this money is going to help with the operating expenses of Shamsud-Din Studio related to the calendar project during this time, including space, utilities, and supplies. This is the place where I make art and where my collaborators work with me to create, document, and share everything that we're doing. If you would like to help with my studio expenses directly, you can provide ongoing support on Patreon or make a donation at GoFundMe. BAM! I can get to these funds more quickly than through Indiegogo. I'm dedicated to art and community engagement that lifts and celebrates black lives. Your support is amazing! We'll provide more detailed information as we get it, but we can't wait—this calendar needs to get printed NOW, and my team of supporters and I think a rolling start is the best way to get moving.

More about me

I was treated as a child prodigy by age 11. In 1955, I won a national art competition and a scholarship, attending the Midwestern Music and Art Camp at the University of Kansas in the summers when I was 14, 15 and 16. But by my Junior year in high school I became disenchanted with school and almost dropped out. A turbulent home life following the break up and divorce of my parents, an oppressive racial environment and the exclusion of black people in the curriculum created feelings of alienation and resentment in me. I descended into street life after graduating and became a thug. It was the continued pursuit of making art and my independent study of the black experience that helped me survive this dangerous, near disastrous time.

Since then, I've been a working artist, a husband and father, a black studies professor, and a community activist. I've been an art instructor from 3rd grade up to college students. Some of the efforts I've led that are similar to this Indiegogo campaign include:

  • Raising funds to design, construct, and run projects that employed and trained professionals and youth apprentices in creating community-based, public art murals—like the Albina Mural Project, Albina Neighborhood Murals, Ojo Tuntun Murals Project, and the Cultural Streams Mural Project.
  • Establishing an African American Visual Arts Scholarship at Portland State University, which helped four students graduate with fine arts degrees.
  • Creating the Young, Black and Gifted art competition with a $10,000 contribution from then-mayor Tom Potter, a "mural marathon" with local volunteer artists, and other benefits to fund cash awards for the winners.
  • Planning, funding, and organizing a series of three Public Art & Murals programs with Guadalupe Rivera Marín, daughter of Diego Rivera.
  • I'll have more detailed information on these projects on my website very soon!

Honey in the Bee Ball, a completed Dawson Park installation funded by the Regional Arts and Culture Council (go check it out, Portlanders!), has consumed much of my time over the last six years, leaving little time to be active in other aspects of my career. Since I finished last summer, I've come back to new works in my studio and pursuing this calendar project.

More than a calendar

The Juneteenth Calendar is a creation that can enlighten and inspire people from all walks of life, in any setting; offices, homes and classrooms, any place there’s a wall to hang it on. It is portable and moderately priced. Teaching Black Studies and creating paintings, drawings and murals—these all reach a limited audience. It can open up new avenues of knowledge and understanding, and make my art accessible to a greater audience. Your support makes you a partner in this greatly needed undertaking.

If we're successful, there will be more than just a calendar. There will be a companion website, programming with libraries and educational organizations around Black History Month and Juneteenth, and the development of new projects building on the ideas of the calendar. We'll create a non-profit so that we can continue to seek funding and collaborate with the amazing people in Portland who are committed to social justice, equity, art-in-action, and telling the stories of disenfranchised people—especially un-erasing the erasure of the black community here.

Our amazing sponsors!

Check this out: if you become a backer, you'll be joining this stellar list of people and organizations who are supporting this calendar project:

  • Arlene Schnitzer, Harold & Arlene Schnitzer CARE Foundation – a long-time personal supporter of mine and the core sponsor of the Juneteenth Calendar
  • Teressa Raiford, Don't Shoot Portland (soon to be the Children's Art and Social Justice Council) and 2020 Portland Mayor candidate – fiscal sponsor (and our vital energy!)
  • Victor Maldonado, professor of art and diversity & inclusion guru at PNCA – documentation and archive sponsor
  • Matt Letzelter, director, Watershed, and professor, PNCA – fine art printmaking sponsor (my collaborator on the limited-edition print perk)
  • NEW! Scott Ballo & Morel Ink – printing sponsor
  • NEW! Tiffany Burnette, Designhype – design sponsor

About the calendar contributors

I created all the art in this calendar over the course of my career. Some of it is earlier, some of it I created under commission, and some of it I've shared in other forms. But never like this. Building on my artwork and my decades of scholarship, I've worked on the development of the calendar with no compensation. All of my work, studio space, and resources so far have been at my own expense. The money that we raise will be put toward supporting the broader goals that I have for the calendar: to educate and inspire! This includes the costs of creating future calendars, so that my work does not continue to be uncompensated. So if successful, we'll budget for compensation for me and for major contributors to work in the future.

I've had major support since this spring from a friend and expert at making technology work for people like me who want to use it as a means to support other interests. She has contributed her time and talent free of charge, teaching me about technology, creating the design and layout of the calendar, editing calendar entries and assisting with research, establishing my presence on the web and social media, and getting this campaign out the door. If we're successful, we'll try to compensate her for future work. She likes to fly under the radar, but I'll call her Elle. When I say "we," know that I'm talking about her and my other close, long-time supporting family members and friends.

If we had to figure in the cost of the work we've both put in, we'd have to raise a heck of a lot more than $15,000, that's the stomp down truth.

We've had tremendous help from my son, Ishaq Shamsud-Din, in more ways than I can recount. And we're especially grateful to Elijah Hassan, a fellow at Open Signal and the videographer who created our campaign video. Also thanks to Yugen Rashad, KBOO radio host, for promoting this project on the air on his program.

Check my website, isakashamsuddin.com, for more information about my major donors and collaborators, my Patreon patrons, and my other sustaining supporters.

story:
Summary:

I am creating a mobile, moving artwork exploring my childhood journeys from the Midlands to coastal holidays in the South West, the memories, the excitement, the early starts, the car sickness, the model villages and our ever-present and trusty Volvos.

Part homage, part personal journey, part wacky races and part serious investigation of the place holidays have in our lives, this project will ultimately form the core of a new body of work to be exhibited in venues tbc.

Project Outline:

The project has multiple strands but with the main focus being a recreation of the Volvo that was used to transport our family to our annual seaside pilgrimage, but with some extensive modifications. Using an existing Volvo of similar spec it will be made as close as possible to my memories of the journeys, from body colour to the seat pockets full of Softmints and i-Spy books. The main difference will be the addition of a large faux neon arrow. This arrow will sit atop the roof as an illuminated beacon signalling the excitement, intent and direction of the journey to be ‘Westward Ho!’. The arrow alludes to roadside signage, the glitz of seaside piers and amusement arcades whilst referencing prior work and the promise of the great American West.

The completed vehicle will be transported to our perpetual starting point of the village of Blisworth in Northamptonshire and then driven towards the South West along routes taken gleaned from memories and old maps. Stopping at our regular stopping points including Frome and Avebury before arriving at one of our common destinations of Westward Ho!

The journey acts like a pilgrimage, a way to honour the memory of my late father (the catalyst for these holidays making them a priority each year). The rituals involved will be followed, from checking of tyre pressures, leaving promptly at 5.30am, and stopping for breakfast on route and avoiding motorways at all cost.

The project is a way to explore my own childhood experiences, my relationship with travel, the coast and the joy and anguish of the long 5+ hour journey. The piece will later journey to other locations, becoming an object for starting discussions with communities and tourists alike as well as forming the centrepiece of an exhibition.

The whole journey will be extensively documented with 'drivers eye' video and photographs on route which will form part of the exhibition.

What I Need:

Having been fortunate to receive some funding through Cultivator Cornwall for equipment to make the Neon Arrow the rest of the project is fully self-funded and this is where I need your support to help make the project happen.

Costs:

  • £900 - 1985 Volvo 340 - Already purchased and modified with some mechanical and cosmetic work still to do
  • £800 -Materials - As well as the expensive faux neon, I need to purchase wood and paint for the arrow steel for the custom roof rack as well as various fixings, and electronics.
  • £200 - Travel expenses - Petrol, travel costs and accommodation en route for the volvo and accompanying documentary vehicle.
 
I am able to fund a lot of the project myself but really need to get to the £1000 goal to make it a reality that it could happen. Any above that and I may even be able to pay myself a fee.
 

What do you Get?

As well as satisfaction for helping make an artwork happen that would otherwise have stalled in the development stage I'm offering a limited edition artists multiple featuring key elements from the project, new artworks and supporting accessories.  There will also be some additional lower value perks available with more to be added.

The full 'Westward Ho!' Box - £30

This is the main perk for your support, A limited edition of 50 'Full boxes', all signed and numbered with a personalised message will be made containing the following:

These will be posted out to you or delivered in person.

  • 'Keyring' book - An A6 book featuring images from my childhood collection of keyrings, each one bought as a souvenir of a place travelled on our family holidays. (1 of 50)
  • 'Volvo on Holiday' book - An A6 book featuring holiday photos of the Volvos either sitting as part of a family portrait or as an ever present part of the holiday landscape.  (1 of 50)
  • Car arrow screenprint - An A4 3 colour screenprint diagram of the Volvo complete with grill teeth and Arrow design (1 of 50)
  • Tax Disc poster - An A2 (folded) digital print featuring all the taxdiscs from the Volvos I travelled on holiday in covering a 13 year period. (1 of 50)
  • I-Spy postcards - A set of 8 postcards featuring the covers of the car journey essential 'I-Spy' books. Providing homage to their ability to combat boredom while contributing to car-sickness. (1 of 50)
  • I-Spy multiple digital print - An A4 digital print of an artwork created from multiple I-Spy book covers
  • Route Map - A digitally printed reproduction of a route map showing the journey the project will take. A2, folded in map style (1 of 50)
  • Car Stickers - A set of stickers for your car of favourite holiday attractions and locations. Based on original stickers, keyrings and badges from our holidays with a newly designed 'I'm Westward Ho!' sticker (1 of 50)
  • I'm Westward Ho! badge - A button badge to show your support with the 'I'm Westward Ho! logo. (not limited to 50)
  • Westward Ho! stick of Rock - A stick of Rock from Westward Ho! with custom insert. Ever present on holidays but never purchased due to being bad for you teeth (1 of 50)
  • Softmints - Always present on car journeys to combat car sickness, these are limited edition redesigned 1980's style packets with Westward Ho! branding. (1 of 50)

That's the box, what else is available?

  • Personalised Westward Ho! Postcard - £5- A postcard sourced from a gift shop in Westward Ho! lovingly written with details of the trip, the weather and local attractions posted to person / address of your choice
  • Car Stickers Mug -£15 - A ceramic mug featuring the destinations car stickers

There may be more to come as I finalise details on other potential perks!

Note: All images used are mock-ups and preliminary designs: Actual designs may vary

 

Timeframe:

  • Preliminary date for postage of boxes is currently June 2019
  • Other perks will be sent in June except for postcards which will be sent as part of the project.
  • Main Project will happen in August 2019, more details will be shared with supporters

Other Ways You Can Help

I'm looking for partner organisations and galleries to team up with on route or as potential venues for displaying all or part of the completed exhibition after the event.

Get in touch if you can help or have any suggestions.

'Volvo on Holiday' book - An A6 book featuring holiday photos of the Volvos either sitting as part of a family portrait or as an ever present part of the holiday landscape.  (1 of 50)

Car arrow screenprint - An A4 3 colour screenprint diagram of the Volvo complete with grill teeth and Arrow design (1 of 50)

Tax Disc poster - An A2 (folded) digital print featuring all the taxdiscs from the Volvos I travelled on holiday in covering a 13 year period. (1 of 50)

I-Spy postcards - A set of 8 postcards featuring the covers of the car journey essential 'I-Spy' books. Providing homage to their ability to combat boredom while contributing to car-sickness. (1 of 50)

I-Spy multiple digital print - An A4 digital print of an artwork created from multiple I-Spy book covers

Route Map - A digitally printed reproduction of a route map showing the journey the project will take. A2, folded in map style (1 of 50)

Car Stickers - A set of stickers for your car of favourite holiday attractions and locations. Based on original stickers, keyrings and badges from our holidays with a newly designed 'I'm Westward Ho!' sticker (1 of 50)

I'm Westward Ho! badge - A button badge to show your support with the 'I'm Westward Ho! logo. (not limited to 50)

Westward Ho! stick of Rock - A stick of Rock from Westward Ho! with custom insert. Ever present on holidays but never purchased due to being bad for you teeth (1 of 50)

Softmints - Always present on car journeys to combat car sickness, these are limited edition redesigned 1980's style packets with Westward Ho! branding. (1 of 50)


That's the box, what else is available?


Personalised Westward Ho! Postcard - £5- A postcard sourced from a gift shop in Westward Ho! lovingly written with details of the trip, the weather and local attractions posted to person / address of your choice

Car Stickers Mug -£15 - A ceramic mug featuring the destinations car stickers


There may be more to come as I finalise details on other potential perks!
Note: All images used are mock-ups and preliminary designs: Actual designs may vary
 

Timeframe:

Preliminary date for postage of boxes is currently June 2019
Other perks will be sent in June except for postcards which will be sent as part of the project.
Main Project will happen in August 2019, more details will be shared with supporters


Other Ways You Can Help
I'm looking for partner organisations and galleries to team up with on route or as potential venues for displaying all or part of the completed exhibition after the event.
Get in touch if you can help or have any suggestions.

story:
As every year at the same time we launch our new supporters campaign.
Without your support it would be difficult for us to be there.
You're not only buying Cds, Lps or tshirts, you're helping bands and labels to release authentic art.
You can imagine how it's hard to produce deviant arts in a liberal world without no rules.
The paradigm of alternative cultures has changed.
We are endangered species...
Do you want it ends? Do you want it continues?
You're an actor of your scene !!!

 

We will produce 5Lps in 2k19 (including new albums from MOAAN EXIS, 2KILOS&MORE, HINTERWELT etc...) and probably some digital contents.

CDs sales are unfortunately worst and worst every year and we will probably stop to manufacture it.

So we propose you to trust in us and to help us for one more noisy year.

3 different perks are proposed :

1- Full supporter : 5 LP's ( to be release in 2k19) + 1 Tshirt

2- limited silkscreen poster of the trauma insect logo.

3- A new design Tshirt "trauma insect"

SPREAD THE TRAUMA and

BECOME an AUDIOTRAUMA SUPPORTER 2k19 !!!
