story:
About the art work

I create black and white art works - paintings, drawings, prints and installations - inspired by landscape and the sea.  I am interested in exploring light and darkness and the meditative and restorative potential of time spent being in nature.  My responses to places are developed in series or as installations, representing the way I experience landscape - not just looking at it, but moving through it, being in it. 

I have visited the Isle of Wight and sailed in the Solent as inspiration for my work for 20 years and I moved to Carisbrooke 2 years ago. In May 2017 I took part in ‘Walk the Wight’ a 26.5 mile charity walk across the Island from the Easternmost point to the Westernmost point - and realised that it is possible to walk from Carisbrooke to the coast, in every and any direction.  Inspired by this experience, and the Richard Long exhibition that was being shown at Quay Arts at that time, I decided to set out on foot in all directions from my studio in the centre of the Island and began a new body of work exploring and responding to the Isle of Wight landscape. 

About the exhibition

Two of my paintings were selected for the Quay Arts Open exhibition 2017, titled ‘I must down to the seas again' and I was awarded first prize of a 2019 solo show in their main gallery - the West Gallery.  The show is programmed to open on 27th April and continues until 29th June 2019.  I am very excited about the opportunity to exhibit new and large scale work in this wonderful space.

Quay Arts' Visual Arts Manager Georgia Newman says "Quay Arts' biennial contemporary Open exhibitions aims to support emerging and established artists through providing a platform to showcase their current work. Through awarding Caroline a solo exhibition, we aim to help elevate her professional practice through the development of a very ambitious body of work, and we intend to support her throughout that process."

Quay Arts (registered charity Steve Ross Foundation for the Arts, Charity No 272007) is situated within an ex-brewery warehouse on the banks of the River Medina and is the leading Arts Centre on the Isle of Wight. Quay Arts supports the development and display of new work by contemporary visual artists. The West Gallery was designed by award-winning architect Tony Fretton (Camden Arts Centre, Lisson Gallery, ArtSway) and presents work of national and international interest. It has hosted eclectic exhibitions including solo shows by Rachel Whiteread, Andy Goldsworthy, Kurt Jackson, Martin Creed and more recently, Richard Long.

What we need & what you get

Although a charity and the central creative hub for artists and communities on the Isle of Wight, Quay Arts receives no ongoing funding to support its core costs and relies on business partnerships and donations from generous individuals to meet its running costs and to support its live, visual and education programme. 

In hosting this solo show, Quay Arts is providing in-kind support, including curatorial and installation support, gallery invigilation and running costs, website running costs, and in-house financial management, admin and marketing support. But to support the basic gallery overheads during the exhibition of my work we need to raise a minimum of £2,400.  

I also need to raise additional funds to cover the materials I’m using to create work for the show, including materials for the installation of large scale pieces and the cost of framing works on paper.  As the gallery is so spacious, the exhibition provides a very special opportunity for me to showcase some of my large work.  This will be the biggest exhibition of my work to date and requires investment to present and showcase the work well and present a high quality exhibition.  

In exchange for financial support I can offer my art work, time and skills. For a limited time, I am offering a 20% discount on art work sales, commissions and workshop bookings through this page, in order to raise advance funds for the exhibition - so if you have been considering buying or commissioning a painting, this is a very good time to do so!

Corporate sponsorship

Do you know a business that might be interested in sponsoring the exhibition?

Quay Arts and I are working together to offer a corporate sponsorship package.

As a charity with no core funding, Quay Arts relies on the generous support from private and public donors to provide an exciting visual arts programme, free for all to access. We are seeking sponsorship to cover the gallery overheads and my installation costs.

As well as opportunities for promotion before and during the exhibition, the sponsor would receive 5 years membership of the Corporate Quayholders' Scheme. We can also host a corporate private view of the exhibition for you, an artist tour or workshop and I can offer a painting for your collection - first choice from all the works available in the exhibition or you could opt to commission a bespoke piece.

This may be of interest to an organisation based on the Isle of Wight or further afield. The exhibition explores the Island, its landscape and coast as experienced on foot. The sea is a recurring theme with several large seascapes, including a new painting on a disused XOD sail.

Ways to help

If you are interested in supporting this exhibition, we would like to invite you to get involved via this campaign.  Please click the pink button at the top of this page, choose what level of support you would like to offer and what you would like in return.  You can also help by sharing this page with anyone else who you think might be interested.  Your support is greatly appreciated.

story:
I was presented with an opportunity to study with master visionary painter Oleg Korolev this spring in Montenegro.
I’m asking for support from my community in order to make it happen.

Your contribution will help cover the costs of my tuition, living expenses and flights. I’m offering some great perks and even the smallest contribution means so much to me. 

If you can't contribute but would like to help, please hit that share button and tell all of your friends.

Blessed Be!

Thank You for believing in my mission!

story:
About Me

When I was about five, my grandmother taught me how to sew. It's been my most defining skill throughout my entire life. In middle school and high school, I loved sewing my own clothing and costumes. Afterwards, I worked in a tailor shop followed by a leathercrafting store. It was during my time at the tailor shop that I won a gift card to an online retailer of various sewing machines. I had my eye on one that could sew through leather, but the first thing I saw was the single-needle Brother PE770 Home Embroidery Machine. Intrigued, I did a few weeks of research. I looked up software, how to design, and what other materials or tools I might need. My mind was set! Now here I am, with that single-needle as well as a professional ten-needle machine.

The goal of my business has always been to hire other independent artists and support them through sales. I wouldn't have been able to start doing that without my best friend, Teal Sather, to be my first business partner. Since starting my portfolio with her beautiful illustration work, I've also had the immense pleasure of licensing work from three other artists. That number will hopefully continue to grow!

 

About My Campaign

What I Am Asking For:

(Edit 11/2/18): In addition to securing a, well, security blanket for the year, the space comes "as-is" and will need a few hundred dollars of renovations before it's ready. So far I've spent about $150 on paint, spackle, light fixtures/bulbs, and the miscellaneous tools that I didn't already have. Every hour that I'm fixing up the place is also time spent away from selling and creating new product, so the quicker I can get this done the less money I'll be out from that perspective. 

My goal for this campaign is set at a year's worth of rent. All funds except a deposit fee and first month's rent will go into my business savings account immediately. Each month, I will only take out what I need for rent. In all likelihood, I will be able to make each month’s rent just fine from profits alone. However, there’s always the risk of off-months, and that's what this fund is for: security. I have no doubt that by one year from now, I will be more than capable of selling enough each month to make rent and then some. But for now, I'm going to need a bit of a security blanket just in case. If I end up not needing any amount of the funds in the savings account, the funds will stay there until absolutely necessary.

If my goal is not reached, the funds will go into a savings account that I've set up specifically for growing my business. No matter how close to my goal I get, I will still be able to sign a lease! I am privileged to have the ability to be confident in my future success. This campaign is simply to start that future with a steadier foothold.

Backer Rewards:

  • $5 - Your name and/or business link on my website and social media
  • $10 - Sticker Set
    • One sticker sheet with art based on the prompts of all backer perks
  • $15 - Single Small Patch
    • 3" patch made from art based on the title "Filomentaur"
  • $30 - Beanie
    • Beanie cap featuring art based on the titles "Twill-o-the-wisp"
  • $35 - T-shirt
    • T-shirt in your selected size featuring art based on the title "Stitch Litch"
  • $50 - Large Patch
    • 7.5" patch made with art based on the title "Design Flayer"
  • $100 - Framed/hooped piece
    • Hand-framed art featuring art based on the title "Hoopagriff"
  • $500 - Sticker Set, five small patches, T-shirt or beanie, large patch, and framed piece
    • All of the above!

If I make it to my goal before the end date, I will be announcing some stretch goals!

Why It's Important:

I’ve been working out of my home for four years now, and the amount of orders I receive per month continues to rise. For a while, I could manage from my current setup, but now I’m hitting the limits of what I can do with the space I have.

Separating my work from home would allow me to take on more custom projects. For example: keeping blank items such as caps, shirts, and a wide range of fabric choices are impossible in my current space. Keeping more items in stock would allow me to offer a better selection of goods to independent artists.  Having the appropriate space to place more machinery - or even hire a part-time employee to assist with item creation - is vital to the growth of any small business.

Being able to provide services to small businesses and local organizations that don’t have the resources to engage with larger industrial embroidery operations is very important to me!  I want to keep my business open to working with both end-users and resellers. That’s why I will continue to not have a minimum quantity requirement.

Current Space:

Right now, I'm using some space in our rented house. It's completely non-insulated while being in the basement. It gets so cold during the cold months that I can hardly be in my studio for half an hour at a time. The rafters are exposed, and our landlord has been storing all sorts of spare wood and tools in them. In addition, there's exposed wiring and only three outlets. It's also taking up an entire room in our house - one we'd prefer to use for storage or a living space.

It's certainly not terrible aside from the temperature, but it's not great either. There's no built in lighting (I had to hang lamps), the door hardly works, and it's so hard to focus when I can just go upstairs and take a nap instead. 

(Here it is! Bad lighting, storage in the corner, and just so smol.)

(So many wires just sort of hanging out.)

(Some day gravity is going to meet this pile of wood that our landlord left in the house.)

New Studio:

On Sept. 27th, we looked at our first prospective studio. It was...not good. I'll leave it at that. Luckily we also had a showing at another building for the next day. We had much better luck there! Out of the four we looked at, two were excellent! One of those two was absolutely perfect.

It's 900sq.ft. of heated, improvable space! It's listed "as-is," which means we're getting a steal on the rental price! We're also able to make improvements as needed, and we'll be starting with a new coat of paint. The reasons it's listed "as-is" are mostly superficial. The ceilings are pretty low at 6'10", there's a boiler room access for the maintenance, and it's pretty narrow. None of these are remotely inconvenient to me, and I love the layout of the room. Lower ceilings mean less space for the heat to escape. There's a room within the room for me to put Teal and her illustrations. We'll even have our own door to the parking lot! Best of all, it's only about 2 miles away from home. I can drive a short distance or take a relaxing bus ride.

(Oh, did I forget to mention the built-in storage space!?)

(Took this picture while in-focus and well-lit; turned out very haunted looking. I'm so into it!)

(Our door! The current door is sealed, but the management is going to replace it with a new operable one.)

The Challenges:

I am so close to making enough money to comfortably afford this space without as big a risk. My business continues to grow leaps and bounds year-over-year, but I’m not quite there yet. Getting this campaign funded would be a huge jump-start.

Even if the goal isn’t met, I am committed to the continuation of my growth as a business owner. This means putting in long work hours, sweat, and probably some tears along the way. I am wholly prepared for this wonderful career path I have set myself upon.

If you can’t provide financial support, I completely understand - you can still help by sharing the campaign on facebook, twitter, and elsewhere! The more the word spreads, the more likely each goal is to be met! Even after the end of this campaign, you can support me by purchasing from my online shop or further supporting me via Patreon.

Where Else to Find Me

Etsy | Instagram | Patreon | Facebook | Twitter | Tumblr

story:
Chapel Perilous is an interactive ruin — dark, mysterious, and illuminated from within. Its two remaining walls, built to resemble distressed stone, stand 16 feet tall. Four stained “glass” windows and a large rosette made from acrylic are lit by LEDs, programmed to display memorizing light patterns. At the chapel’s center is an interactive altar, which visitors can manipulate to trigger new light patterns and sounds.Residents of Black Rock City are invited to explore the ruin if they dare.

Until Chapel Perilous finds its way to Burning Man 2019, Rob and the Enchanted Booty Forest will be hard at work creating four beautiful stained glass windows, building the chapel’s frame, spires, and interactive art pieces, as well as imbuing the structure with the power of chaos magic!Chapel Perilous received an honoraria grant for over $14,000, but it’ll cost about $23,000 to build it sturdily enough to withstand the harsh conditions of the playa and to transport it to Black Rock City and back. We need your help!

 

But who is Rob? And what is an Enchanted Booty Forest?

Four years ago, Rob took a leap of faith. He’d been building a successful but ultimately unfulfilling career at a large bank, but he left it all behind and built a small workshop in his apartment where he could experiment with laser cutting and making art.

He’s spent thousands of hours designing and laser cutting since then, learning lots of new tools and developing an artistic style along the way. Chapel Perilous is the biggest project he’s taken on yet, and the culmination of a lot of hard work to this point.

But it’s not just Rob’s work and ideas that have led to this project’s creation—over 25 artists are coming together to design, engineer, build, decorate, and otherwise bring this ruined chapel to life. Mostly hailing from Los Angeles, the members of this team have a variety of expertise but are all driven by the same call to bring an amazing experience to the citizens of Black Rock City and beyond. The crew comes together under the Enchanted Booty Forest art collective, which is also a village of Black Rock City.

 

Alright, but what’s the point?

We’re building a physical manifestation of the eight-circuit model of consciousness because it’s really, really special. Each of the eight circuits represents a type of intelligence. Developing them can help you experience bliss, reimagine your limitations, overcome trauma, connect to your genetic memory, access the Akashic records, and perhaps even understand the true nature of existence. It’s basically a path to unlocking the secrets of the universe, so we’re building a beautiful, rapture-inducing playground for burners to explore it.

As part of that exploration, chapel guardians will guide burners through some of the symbols in the piece and offer support through personal transformation, if desired. An altar will stand in the middle, an offering of an ideal setting for personal or group rituals dedicated to growth and transformation. We’re building a stomping grounds for people to experiment with both practical and magical methods of changing their lives, and we hope you’re excited to support it!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our Honoraria grant is covering a lot of the engineering, material, and build costs to create the chapel. But, in order to stand up to the harsh conditions of the playa, the project requires a previously unexpected $5,000 worth of aluminum truss. We also need to raise another $4-5,000 for transportation, decor, audio equipment, computer, Production Designer, and the necessary enclosures to keep all the electronics clean and cool.In addition to the satisfaction of knowing you’ve personally helped our crew and all the chapel’s visitors to progress along their paths, here’s what your donations will get you at various levels:

 

Perks

$15  Thank you -  Your support for this project at any level is appreciated.

$30  Postcard - We'll take professional photos of the chapel for these post cards. Our build crew will send you a handwritten note of thanks on the back after the event!

$50   Sigil - Everything above PLUS: Draw your own magick sigil to call in or release something that's meaningful to YOU! (Don't worry—we'll teach you how.) Send it in, and we'll put it in part of one of the chapel walls then we'll take it to the temple to burn on Sunday night.

$100  Sticker pack - Everything above PLUS: a sticker pack including images of each of the Chapel's stained glass windows.

$250 Photo print - Everything above PLUS: a gorgeous, professional printed art photo of the chapel on the playa.

$500  12" Epoxy Rosette - You get a postcard, sigil, sticker pack, AND a 12" replica of the chapel's rosette window, made using the same painted epoxy technique as the original 48" rosette! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for animators and motion graphic artists to help us make custom content for the LED windows. No amount of content is too little! If you'd like to help with this, email rob.

You can also follow @exitchapelperilous on Instagram to stay in the loop!

story:
Now more than ever in American history is it important to know and understand the true story of Eugene Debs, and the history and effects of what the socialism movement really meant at the start of the 20th century in the US.

Some current political beliefs have taken to using the word socialism as 'anti-American,' when if fact the movement was meant to help the everyday American.

Prisoner 9653 For President - Eugene Victor Debs, will look at how it was that this man stood up to corporate pressures of the day and spoke out for the young men who were going off to war.

Prisoner 9653 For President - Eugene Victor Debs, will consider policies like The Espionage Act and how they limit what are supposed to be our civil rights.

This play is not only intended to tell the story of the past, but to look at the present, and future of America's political system -- to show what can be done when we choose to stand up and speak out -- even if it means going to jail.

This audio play will contain valuable information for you and millions of others throughout the world, because it brings to light the story of a man whose name may not (yet) be familiar, but whose ideas set the foundation of Roosevelt's New Deal.

Debs traveled the country and campaigned on behalf of those often disenfranchised workers.  Debs was sentenced to 10 years in prison for being against America's involvement in World War One, a war in which "old rich men profited while young men died". Sound familiar?

We live in a great nation of different opinions - we need to have a more intelligent and factual conversation, particularly about our own history. This was important then, but is even more important now! The 2020 elections will be here soon. If we don't know the history, we can't change the future!

Once the play is written by May 2019, it will be presented in a workshop on the stage of the National World War I Museum and Memorial as part of the annual HEAR Now Festival.

 This will give the playwrights an opportunity to fine tune the material and get it ready for a studio recording in Fall 2019. The completed production will be released for public radio stations to use on President's Day 2020.

ABOUT OUR TEAM

Yale Strom is a filmmaker, writer, musician, composer, photographer, and award winning audio playwright. Time Magazine wrote, "Through his art, Strom has brought back his spiritual klezmer ancestors". Having made and produced many productions, from films to radio plays, he knows how to complete a project to time and get it out to his audience.

Elizabeth Schwartz has been producing in the entertainment industry for many years, and along with Yale has written and produced numerous award winning works in video and audio.

Sue Zizza is an award winning audio director and producer who is bringing this play to the National WWI Museum and Memorial as part of the 2019 HEAR Now Festival. Sue's work has been heard nationally and internationally.

WHAT WE NEED

We need to raise a minimum of $3,500.00.  All of this will go toward the initial writing, developement, and producing of the audio play Prisoner 9563 for President - Eugene Victor Debs. We intend to release the project for free to public radio stations nationally in time for President's Day January 2020.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

By contributing what you can, you will help to bring this audio play to fruition before the 2020 presidential elections. 

For many years, and most recently, the word "socialism" has been bandied about as if it were the greatest threat to our freedoms. These same types of politicians made those same kind of claims when FDR instituted the New Deal and created Social Security and Medicare. 

These ideas for America and its workers came from Eugene Victor Debs, a pioneering labor organizer and co-founder of The Socialist Party of America, who was profoundly influenced by his faith and sense of social justice and responsibility. This audio play will further help to remind us about how we can work together, by telling the life story of someone whose values and ideals gave us the five-day work week and an end to child labor. I need your help to do that.

Even if you can't afford to donate $5.00, you can still help tremendously by sending our campaign to all of your friends and family members who you believe will support our audio play. As you know, it's all about the numbers. If two hundred people each give $5.00, we've raised $1,000.00.


Please share this IndieGoGo campaign to everyone in your social media lists (Facebook, emails, Twitter, etc.) and help us achieve our goal of raising funds to produce this film.

story:
The Archaeopteryx 

 Rising from the dust, our sculpture invites you to touch, explore, and inhabit.  In order to activate her fullest potential; people must work together. Through collaboration participants can mobilise her 16ft wingspan and activate beautiful illuminating light graphics.

The Archaeopteryx serves as a physical and symbolic reminder that in order for humans to evolve, we must work together.

We need your help to finish the work we've started and bring her to the playa. 

 

...and this is pretty cool

The fabric wings become a canvas for participants to explore via live generative graphics inspired by the work of pioneering computer scientist Allan Turing.  As they are seated, pressure and proximity sensors detect and relay their presence into the projection canvas where one's virtual "cell" is able to grow, divide, and merge with other participants in real time

 

Philosophy 

The work is open to multiple interpretations.  We like the idea that it might help one to see and situate themselves in an evolving and connected world.  By drawing parallels between the primal nature of evolution and the current human condition, we believe it has a powerful message that empowers others to evolve towards a better future; one that is more inclusive, equitable, and harmonious.  From the individual to the collective scale, the theme encapsulates the characteristics of something much larger than itself.

 

Who are we? 

Wevolve Labs is an international team of architects, creatives, makers, programmers, scientists, and engineers from USA, and UK, who work together to create projects that bring people together and contribute towards a positive future. 

 We believe creativity is something we all share in common and has the power to inspire change.

 

Why we need your help 

This is our biggest, most ambitious project to date.

We are now working hard to raise additional funds to cover:

  • - Tools and equipment
  • - Raw materials
  • - Technical systems and lighting
  • - Transportation to the playa   

The best way to help make the Archaeopteryx possible by donating whatever you can afford $10 - £1000! Is truly welcome!

 

What you'll get in addition to helping the project

We’ve got some incredible rewards, and collector's items, listed on the right of this page! Including;

  • T-shirts
  • Pendants
  • Wall Prints 

..and you can even get your own message engraved on the Archaeopteryx herself!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways to work together on the project are to help spread the word on social, volunteer to join the team, or just come and see us on playa later this year!  

 

Find Out More

-Keep up to date with regular progress updates on our Instagram: @wevolve.labs

-Find out more details on our website: www.archaeopteryx.info

story:
A half century in the making and just in time to mark our 10th anniversary in Las Vegas...the Burlesque Hall of Fame is ready to pull back the curtain on our NEW HOME!

The Burlesque Hall of Fame, the world's only not-for-profit organization with a mission to preserve, celebrate and inspire the art of burlesque, is thrilled to announce that in 2016 we will take the keys to a newly renovated museum, exhibition, retail and office venue, and begin installation for a grand opening in the summer!

This is a tremendously thrilling--but also challenging--time in the history of the Burlesque Hall of Fame! And your support will play a vital role in our success.

So what's The Big Reveal all about?

Above: Miss Exotic World 1995, Pillow, outside the gates to our original home, the Exotic World Museum in the Mojave Desert of California.

The move to our new home launches the third era in BHoF's history. The first was the era of our beginnings as a small, dusty roadside attraction, a museum of memorabilia collected by our founder, Jennie Lee, from her compatriots in the business of tease. Jennie began the annual reunion of the performers from burlesque's heyday, and from those seeds our events and the collection grew. The annual Miss Exotic World Pageant was founded by the legendary Dixie Evans, as a way to draw new fans and performers to the museum. 

Above: Dixie Evans, "The Marilyn Monroe of Burlesque" in our original home.

The second key point in our history was in the early 2000s, when a small group of volunteers, representing the next generation of burlesque enthusiasts from around the world, took on the challenge of preserving this one-of-a-kind collection of costumes, props, photos, ephemera and more and of making it an organized, permanent and official not-for-profit institution dedicated to celebrating and preserving an often-overlooked area of entertainment history. This is the era when we became the Burlesque Hall of Fame, moved the collection to Las Vegas and our primary fundraiser, the annual Burlesque Hall of Fame Weekender, became the four-day showcase it is today. Held every year on the first weekend in June in Las Vegas, the BHoF Weekender is attended by thousands of fans and contemporary burlesque performers, with nightly performances, vendors, classes, panel discussions and parties—and of course, the reunion of the elder stars of yesteryear.  

Our 2013 exhibition "Not-So-Hidden Histories: Performers of Color in Burlesque."

And now, we’ve reached a third pivotal point, when the Burlesque Hall of Fame, the museum itself, can begin to match the international stature of its main event, and become a true destination for fans, tourists and scholars alike! 

The Burlesque Hall of Fame is currently housed in a small storefront space of only 220 square feet, inadequate to properly exhibit and store our growing collection and support our growing audience.

Our new home in Las Vegas’s art district will include:

  • 3,000 square feet of exhibition and program space (which will provide room for rotating exhibitions on a variety of themes featuring the more 3,500 artifacts in our collection (including costumes, props, photos, posters, written material and much more)
  • Spaces specifically for programs such as performances, readings, classes and events, as well as offices, a retail gift shop, and space to store, catalogue and preserve our unique collection 

So, how can you help?

The build-out and preparation of our new home comes with some very real costs, and we remain a small, grassroots not-for-profit organization. 

We need your help to raise at least $50,000 to open our new doors. Costs include:

  • The architectural design of our new interior spaces
  • Professional wall construction for 150 linear feet of display walls (nearly 3 times what we have now!)
  • Flooring installation, including for a professional-quality performance, teaching and event space
  • Museum-quality lighting installation
  • New signage both inside the space and outside on our new building
  • Display cases, shelving, and other installation supplies
  • Building and installation of safe, professional storage and work space where our collection can be preserved, catalogued and accessed by scholars and fans 

There's a lot to be done, but with friends like you, we know that we can achieve it!

BHoF isn't "just" about burlesque. If you're interested in vaudeville, comedy, theater, dance, fashion, glamour, underground art, women, feminism, labor movements, the USO, LGBTQ communities or censorship, then you have a reason to care about the Burlesque Hall of Fame. And your support will be the foundation on which our next great era is built!

And to thank our donors, we've got great perks at every level!

  • At the $10-$50 levels, receive a personalized thank you card, Big Reveal tote bag and your name listed among our inaugural donors in the museum 
  • At the $100 level, we'll add a set of pasties with your name to BHoF's permanent new WALL OF PASTIES in our new home
  • At the $150 level, the opportunity to provide your own custom pair pasties for the WALL OF PASTIES or have a special, glittering pair made for your place on the Wall by New York City's Glorious Pasties
  • At the $250 level, amazing benefit packages including a one-year subscription to Bachelor Pad magazine and rare collectibles from  past BHoF Weekends 


    The first 6 donors at $250 can receive this extremely rare fine art print by famed illustrator Paul Pope

  • At the $500 level, fabulous benefit packages including a two-night stay and dinner at the Orleans Hotel and Casino, Swarovski crystal-encrusted bow ties from Haute Under the Collar, two years of Bachelor Pad magazine, a pair of ostrich-feather fans from Fancy Feather and more
  • At the $1,000 level, your name as a sponsor of the new BHoF permanent exhibition
  • At the $2,500 level, your name listed as the sponsor of a specific, marquee item in the collection
  • At the $5,000 level, you'll be listed as a presenting sponsor of the inaugural exhibition of the new BHoF, including a hard hat tour of the space with our Executive Director
  • Donate $10,000, and you'll have the opportunity to name the Gallery at the new BHoF until 2021, and enjoy a private opening event with burlesque legends, stars and VIPs 

Not sure you can donate now? We still need you! 

Help us spread the word about the campaign!
  • Share this link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and wherever else you connect with your network
  • Help us reach people you know that aren't part of the burlesque community, but who might want to contribute. Send us a message to receive a downloadable fact sheet with all of the info you need to spread the word, and some tips how!
  • Use the hashtag #bigreveal and help build the audience
  • Work somewhere that might become a sponsor? Know people who could help support or donate goods or services to the project? Want to volunteer with the campaign? Want to more details about plans for the new space and our first exhibits? Send us a message!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

currently housed in a small storefront space of only 220 square feet, inadequate to properly exhibit and store our
growing collection and support our growing audience.
Our new home in Las Vegas’s art district will include:



3,000 square feet of exhibition and
program space (which will provide room for rotating exhibitions on a variety of
themes featuring the more 3,500 artifacts
in our collection (including costumes, props, photos, posters, written material
and much more)

Spaces specifically
for programs such as performances, readings, classes and events, as well as offices,
a retail gift shop, and space to store, catalogue and preserve our unique
collection 

So, how can you help?
The
build-out and preparation of our new home comes with some very real costs, and
we remain a small, grassroots not-for-profit organization. 
We need your help to raise at least $50,000 to open our new doors. Costs include:

The architectural design of our new interior spaces
Professional wall construction for 150 linear feet of display walls (nearly 3 times what we have now!)
Flooring installation, including for a professional-quality performance, teaching and event space
Museum-quality lighting installation
New signage both inside the space and outside on our new building
Display cases, shelving, and other installation supplies
Building and installation of safe, professional storage and work space where our collection can be preserved, catalogued and accessed by scholars and fans 

There's a lot to be done, but with friends like you, we know that we can achieve it!
BHoF isn't "just" about burlesque. If you're interested in vaudeville, comedy, theater, dance, fashion, glamour, underground art, women, feminism, labor movements, the USO, LGBTQ communities or censorship, then you have a reason to care about the Burlesque Hall of Fame. And your support will be the foundation on which our next great era is built!

And to thank our donors, we've got great perks at every level!


At the $10-$50 levels, receive a personalized thank you card, Big Reveal tote bag and your name listed among our inaugural donors in the museum 
At the $100 level, we'll add a set of pasties with your name to BHoF's permanent new WALL OF PASTIES in our new home
At the $150 level, the opportunity to provide your own custom pair pasties for the WALL OF PASTIES or have a special, glittering pair made for your place on the Wall by New York City's Glorious Pasties

At the $250 level, amazing benefit packages including a one-year subscription to Bachelor Pad magazine and rare collectibles from  past BHoF Weekends The first 6 donors at $250 can receive this extremely rare fine art print by famed illustrator Paul Pope

At the $500 level, fabulous benefit packages including a two-night stay and dinner at the Orleans Hotel and Casino, Swarovski crystal-encrusted bow ties from Haute Under the Collar, two years of Bachelor Pad magazine, a pair of ostrich-feather fans from Fancy Feather and more
At the $1,000 level, your name as a sponsor of the new BHoF permanent exhibition
At the $2,500 level, your name listed as the sponsor of a specific, marquee item in the collection
At the $5,000 level, you'll be listed as a presenting sponsor of the inaugural exhibition of the new BHoF, including a hard hat tour of the space with our Executive Director
Donate $10,000, and you'll have the opportunity to name the Gallery at the new BHoF until 2021, and enjoy a private opening event with burlesque legends, stars and VIPs 

Not sure you can donate now? We still need you! 

Help us spread the word about the campaign!
Share this link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and wherever else you connect with your network
Help us reach people you know that aren't part of the burlesque community, but who might want to contribute. Send us a message to receive a downloadable fact sheet with all of the info you need to spread the word, and some tips how!
Use the hashtag #bigreveal and help build the audience
Work somewhere that might become a sponsor? Know people who could help support or donate goods or services to the project? Want to volunteer with the campaign? Want to more details about plans for the new space and our first exhibits? Send us a message!



THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
The Firebird Festival is an annual celebration of arts and culture that is held in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. 

This year marks the 12th year of the festival, as it returns to Friendship Field on December 5th, 2015.

http://firebirdfestival.com

The Firebird Festival mission is to provide an annual celebration of the borough of Phoenixville's namesake - the Phoenix. Just as the Phoenix rose from its own ashes, the town of Phoenixville has risen, and continues to rebuild and improve the local community, after the loss of its principle industry in the early 1980's.

The festival is designed to foster a collaboration of local artistic and creative talent, and to enhance the overall cultural life of Phoenixville.

100+ performers, an expansive craft vendor area, and gourmet food trucks and vendors from the Philadelphia and the surrounding suburbs will be on site to welcome the thousands of participants who flock to Phoenixville for the festival. 

There will also be a parade from downtown Phoenixville, leading its way up to Friendship Field. The community is encouraged to join in the parade, which will feature paper lanterns, peace birds, puppets, dancers, drummers and more.

There will be continuous shuttle buses connecting downtown to the bird site at Friendship Field.


Progress

We need to raise $7,000 by November 30th, 2015. If we can raise that amount in our campaign this year, it will give us the ability to do the great things that are planned for the festival this year!

If we can reach our "stretch goal" of $10,000 this year, we will have a head start in securing the future of the festival for next year.

Our campaign is at 51% of the "stretch goal". Your gift will help take us one step closer to reaching $10,000!


How You Can Help

There are many elements that go into the festival, ranging from building the bird and providing a safe and comfortable festival experience for the community, to providing entertainment, obtaining insurance, and promoting the festival.

Below is a breakdown of some of the annual expenses that we incur when putting on the festival:

  • Portable Restrooms - $2,100
  • Stage & Sound System for Musicians and Performers - $2,500
  • Compensation for Musicians and Performers - $1,500
  • Insurance for the Festival - $3,000
  • Posters, Flyers and Printing for Promotional Material and Programs - $1,000
  • Wood and Materials for Construction of the Phoenix - $1,000

We all have a part to play in this wonderful celebration, and we look to each of you, the community, friends and families who have enjoyed this wonderful celebration in the past, to help us achieve 100% of our fundraising goal.

We have been very successful in raising funds in the past, thanks in part to the support of people who gave gifts through our previous Indiegogo campaigns.
Let's keep the fire burning and do it again!

Please join in support of the Firebird Festival by making a gift through this campaign, and by asking family and friends to join you in making a gift.

You can also help by using the social media tools on this page to share this campaign with your friends and family who embrace what the Firebird Festival is doing for the community.

All funds that are raised through this campaign will go to support the purchase of construction materials and goods and services listed above, in order to ensure a safe and exciting Firebird Festival for 2015!

Gift Recognitions and Perks

From smaller gifts to larger gifts - all are important.
Every donation to the campaign is greatly appreciated and put to use.

Please see the list of "perks" for donors along the right side of this page, for what we are able to offer to donors as "thank you" recognitions for continued support.

We are offering T-shirts, mugs, framed prints, canvas prints, and even 5 chances to be "torchbearers" and pass the torch into the Phoenix, lighting it on fire on December 5th, 2015!

With your help, the Phoenix will always rise from its ashes at the Firebird Festival!

story:
Hi. I'm Jayme - fiber artist, female entrepreneur and alpaca farm manager for Sage Hill Farms Alpacas where we have 50 wonderful alpacas & lots of raw alpaca fiber begging to made into something fabulous for someone to wear. I create nuno felted or cobweb scarves and wraps or as I like to call them "Wearable Art". I love designing and creating scarves and wraps.  I love the tactile feel of the fiber in my hands, dyeing it in fantastic colors and shaping it into a luxurious scarf for someone to wear.  I've also decided to add a line of felted embellished arm cuffs and book/ipad covers. 

Currently I lack the ideal tools to take my scarf making from a hobby to a business. The process of dyeing, carding and felting is much longer because I'm working with tiny carders, small crock pots for dyeing in small batches and can only work on one scarf at a time. It's not a very efficient process because of the lack of the correct tools.  I love the process from start to finish but I want to make this work as a business rather than a sideline or hobby.    

My purpose for this campaign is to raise funds to buy equipment that will make the process or making scarves more efficient and there allow me time to produce more scarfs to sell making this a viable business. 
Two examples of how specific equipment would speed up the process:  a drum carder can card large amounts of fiber at one time versus using the small hand carders I am now, which take a long time to card enough fleece for a scarf.  The second example is  an electric EZ Roller Felting Machine, which would allow me to be felting one scarf while I was laying out the design for the next,  Both of these items would speed up production time significantly. The campaign funds would allow me to purchase these items, as well as the other items specifically detailed below,  materials such as dyes, blending fibers and fabric necessary for creating my "Wearable Art"

There are hundreds of pounds of alpaca fiber languishing around here waiting to be made into wearable art or anything you or I can imagine.  I just need a helping hand to start making good use of all that fiber and showing people the luxurious warmth and softness of alpaca fiber.  

Let me tell you a little more about me. I started learning about fiber and fiber art when we purchased our first alpacas 8 years ago. Since then I have discovered a passion for fiber and color that I use to create various kinds of fiber art - scarves, shawls, wraps, Christmas stockings and needle felted creatures. 
My focus right now is on wearable art - scarves & wraps, which I love, but I'm flexible and I like to play around with different ideas all the time. 

Fiber art is a labor of love and artistic expression. Every piece is made by passionate hands with love and hope that it will bring pleasure to the wearer. Wearable art is unique, whimsical and tactile – brightening the soul and comforting with a touch. 

Every scarf I create is infused with a piece of me. Each piece is a reflection of my love of my alpacas, the fiber and my hope that the wearer enjoys it as much as I enjoyed the process of making it. Each piece tells a story. 
Please take a look at my  Etsy shop: Alpaca Whimsy to see examples of some of scarves and other items I've made.   I also have a Facebook page called:  https://www.facebook.com/AlpacaWhimsy. You can also find me on Twitter at @sagehillfarms.

We currently have 50 alpacas who graciously let me utilize their fiber for my "play". Their fiber is a sustainable resource as they grow new fiber every year.  They are wonderful creatures and it gives me real joy to use fiber from animals I love to create art for others to enjoy. Check out the awesome creatures who make this luxurious fiber on my website  Sage Hill Farms Alpacas or on Facebook at Sage-Hill-Farms-Alpacas. 

It would mean the world to me if you would support my ambition of making my love of creating "Wearable Art" into a real business by making it work efficiently with the correct tools.  I love working with my alpaca's fiber and I love the enjoyment people get from my creations. 

What I Need & What You Get

My intention is to use the donations to purchase the following equipment and materials to help speed up the process of making scarves, wraps, stockings & creature creations to increase output.  
The following is a break down of the things I intend to purchase with your much appreciated donations:

Equipment - $4,250

EZ Roller Felting Machine $980.95

Double Treadle Ashford Joy wheel with jumbo flyer $1000

Makita Variable speed 1/2 sheet sander $179

Blending Hackle $108-170

Strauch Mad Batter Drum Carder $790

Needle Felting Sewing Machine $279

Addiquick needle felting tool & needles $180

Dress form for display $100

Triple crockpot for dyeing $100

Large dye pots $150


Materials/Inventory - $500

Dye

Pre-dyed scarves or fabric

Citric acid

Olive Oil Soap

Blending Fibers: mohair, suri, wensleydale, firestar, Angelina, rose fiber, bamboo, merino

In return for your contribution, I have included several different perks based on your donation amount.  These include a extremely grateful thank you, 3 cat toy balls,  a pair of needle felted coasters, a needle felted Christmas Ornament, a needle felted Christmas stocking and a nuno felted or cobweb felted scarf or wrap.  

Your contribution (of any amount) is valuable to me and I appreciate your support.   The pictures below represent examples of the various perks.  Your perks will be individual to you.






The Impact

A lot of people don't even know about the value and luxurious nature of alpaca fiber. I want to create scarves that showcase the qualities of alpaca fiber. It is extremely lightweight, and is often compared to cashmere in terms of weight and softness. It doesn't have the prickle factor that wool has and so most people who find wool itchy won't be bothered by alpaca. It is moisture resistant and warmer than wool.  My alpacas have asked me to share their fabulousness of their fiber with the world and all I can do as a good alpaca owner is comply.

Risks & Challenges

Depending on the number of contributors it may take me a while to complete all the perks as I am just one woman but complete them I will and deliver them in as timely a fashion as possible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute it would be a great help to me if you would share my campaign with all your friends so I can reach as large an audience as possible. Any and all support is extremely appreciated.

story:
I Wanna Marry Someone Who’s Married Already /installation/

Hello, friends. My name's Ilina and I'm a contemporary artist :) My latest project was approved for Sofia Underground Festival 2016 (19-24 April, 2016) but I need help to fund it. It is a hearty, emotional installation of wood branches and wedding accessories. It's also a self-ironic and feminist piece of art that praises love ... Please, guys, help me take it to life <3
My dream art installation is called I Wanna Marry Someone Who’s Married Already  and it consists of 3 conceptually related parts: The Engagement, The Bride, The Wedding Bouquet ( each ~ 2 m tall). It discusses love, wedding garments and my epic fail in getting a good old marriage of convenience :( The pieces that comprise the whole are as follows:

  • Pt.I: The Engagement

A 2-meters-tall wood branch decorated with cheap rings. Propped against a wall or in the corner.

  • Pt.II: The Bride

A bunch of 2-metres-tall wood branches (3-5) in a wedding dress. Propped against a wall or in a corner.

  • Pt.III: The Wedding Bouquet

A bunch of 2-metres-tall wood branches (3-5) decorated with a wedding band. Propped against a wall or in a corner.

To sum up:

•Type: Installation
•Materials: Wood branches + wedding garments
•Dimensions: Variable
•Year of creation: 2016
•Author: Ilina Konsulova
Thanks in advance for your help!

story:
The Big Idea

I am doing a show of landscape photographs that I have been working on for the last two years and this campaign is essentially a pre-sale of the 8 pieces. I will then use those in a solo show in the Fall of 2016 and after that they go home to you.


The Story

I have been shooting landscapes for more than 30 years and have recently hit on a new approach that I am very excited about - a new way of conveying what I find out in nature. What makes these images unique is also what requires them to be printed and mounted in such a specific way and this is what has given rise to this campaign.


The Deal

I am pre-selling 8 of these light boxes for the cost of producing the pieces and mounting the show - this will be one half of the cost of that same image once it is hanging on the wall. Each image will be sold as an edition of 8 with a tiered pricing system meaning as we move through the edition ( 1/8, 2/8, 3/8 ) the price goes up as well. Starting price for the 2/8 photos will be $3600 so you have this opportunity to get them at a great deal.

The images are printed on transparency using a Light Jet printer and are mounted in light boxes that are roughly 4 feet wide and 2 feet high. The frames are hand made by Neil Wilkinson out of beautiful, tight-grain Fir.

I have posted the set of 12 images above, you can also look at them on my website and you can also download them here. Have a look through them, it will be your selections that decide which 8 images will be in the show. 

*Note - There will be some additional re-touching on the final prints, nothing drastic, just minor tweaks.

For shipping, if you are in Vancouver that's easy - you can pick up your piece after the show. If you are further out, contact me and we can price out shipping based on where you are. Note that shipping costs will your responsibility above and beyond the price of the work.


The Impact

Having your support at this stage is crucial - I wouldn't be able to mount a show of this quality and scale without the pre-sales. Having my own show will also allow me to attract attention, forge new relationships with galleries, and let me start working on more of these landscapes as well as the other projects that I have in the works.


Spread the Word

If you know someone who would be interested in this work, feel free to send them this campaign, it can only help.

story:
Who we are and what we want to do

We are Cindy Croot and Joy Katz, a theater director and a poet who co-founded a collective to create pro-beauty, anti-racist art in Pittsburgh (where we live) and other cities. 

ONE LARGE is one of those artworks. It's a collaborative piece about race and money. ONE LARGE distributes $1,000 among 100 people who each read aloud a pledge to spend their part ($10) at a black-owned business. ONE LARGE creates a brief interruption in a flow of money that mainly goes one way—to distant, white business owners. It creates a brief disruption in a system of economic injustice that extracts all of our dollars and impoverishes black communities.  

ONE LARGE premiered in July 2015 in Pittsburgh and garnered local and international press. We were invited to bring ONE LARGE to our nation's capital, Washington D.C., this summer. We need your help to do that. 

By contributing to ONE LARGE, you enable 100 people to think about race and money. They'll discover a black-owned business in their city or online or revisit a favorite business. And your money literally becomes part of the disruption of the constant flow of money to white-owned businesses. 

While in Washington, we also will have access to legislators, and we'll be talking with them about ONE LARGE.


What We Need 

  • We need $3,000 to bring ONE LARGE to D.C.
  • $1,000 of that gets divided among the 100 participants. 
  • The balance ($2,000) covers travel costs (gas, parking, cheap Airbnb for 4 nights) and project documentation: keeping the website running and paying Ricardo Iamuuri, the artist who created the video on this page, for his time.  
  • It takes many hours to edit and code the ONE LARGE page with participants' stories,, We do not get paid for our work. All of your donation goes to the participants and defrays expenses. 

What You Get

You get to interrupt a system of economic plunder in America that has been in place for hundreds of years and that affects black entrepreneurs to this day.

And there are perks. See the sidebar to the right! 

If we exceed our goal of $3,000, the over-and-above goes toward the next two launches of ONE LARGE: Charleston, SC in 2017; and 100 AP American History students at the school for creative and performing arts (CAPA) in Pittsburgh this fall. 


The Impact

ONE LARGE has a big impact for a small investment.

ONE LARGE creates 100 experiences for 100 people who engage with businesses they may not have heard about in their cities and online. ONE LARGE also creates awareness of the unique barriers to entrepreneurship that black business owners face.

ONE LARGE underlines both the variety and the scarcity of black-owned businesses in our country, and it spurs reflection and conversation about communities, race, history, and spending habits. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, and that's okay! You can help in other ways:

  • Look for black-owned businesses in your area (check out the FAQs on the project website).
  • Spread the word about our campaign using the share tools on this page!

Thank you for your support! 

                                         – Cindy and Joy

story:
Chapter 31: An Odd Piece of Research on the Many Virtues of the Oriental Imagination 

(4th August-3rd September 2016)


This summer, we will be holding a group exhibition about the future of Palestine at the P21 Gallery in London.

We - Nadia and Mai - are two curators who have been working on ‘Chapter 31’ for over a year, in both the UK and Palestine. The project means everything to us.

We are very excited to have secured the bulk of our funding but we still need to raise some money for the show to be able to go ahead this year.

This is where YOU come in...


Our vision 

We are aiming to raise £5000

This will go towards promoting Palestinian art and artists in the UK, something we think is of great importance.

The last few years have seen violence soar in Palestine... A new Israeli defence minister has just been sworn in who wants to implement the death penalty for Palestinian ‘militants’. Gaza remains under suffocating blockade whilst Palestinian citizens of the West Bank continue to be routinely detained without charge and executed on the streets.

At this critical time, with Palestine under occupation for nearly seventy years and seven million refugees living in exile with no immediate prospect of return, we are asking ‘what does the future hold for Palestine?’

We believe in the power of art as a vehicle for change, hope and resistance. And we believe that Palestinian artists need to be supported in sharing their visions for the future with new audiences in Britain.

The exhibition will be a dazzling journey into the future, taking audiences in the UK on a voyage through both Palestinian utopias and dystopias, featuring works in film, sculpture, painting, photography, performance and installation.

Our artists include Palestinians from or working in the West Bank, Gaza, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, the USA and Europe. 


Where your money will go

Every penny from your donations will go towards creating the show we have dreamed of, helping to bring this work to London. None of this money is for our salaries: everything will go into the costs of running the exhibition.

Even if we don’t reach our target, your contribution will make a huge difference to the work we are doing.

All donors will be included in our catalogue (if you want to!).

We have some excellent perks on offer too, including limited edition scarves designed by one of our artists and a private curators' tour. Don't miss out!

You can also help us by spreading the word, making some noise and coming along to the exhibition.

We can’t wait to see you there!

website: www.sarhacollective.com 

facebook: www.facebook.com/sarhacollective

insta: www.instagram.com/sarhacollective

twitter: twitter.com/sarhacoolective

story:
Creative Blueprint is coming to Capitol Hill, Seattle


We've been building collaborative communities for more than 10 years now in Toronto, Canada. Creative Blueprint's artist studios and the CB Gallery are currently partnered with the Foundery coworking and event space in Toronto, Ontario.

We are home to a vibrant community of artists and entrepreneurs, and we are committed to helping our members achieve their unique personal and professional goals while developing a self-sustaining and rewarding practice.

We are expanding to the West Coast and to the US to provide studios, services, event and exhibition space in the core of Seattle's first Arts District - Capitol Hill.

We have secured an exciting new space and will be partnering with an incredible coworking community - our friends and neighbors at Office Nomads.


Help us launch our CB Seattle Studios

We have a lot of work ahead of us, and we need your help to raise funds for our first round of renovations.

The money we raise through this campaign will be used to:

  • Build gallery and studio walls for our members
  • Improve and extend the electrical and ventilation systems
  • Upgrade our member access, WiFi and security systems
  • Install track lighting and 2 new windows
  • Complete the kitchen and members lounge

If we reach our fundraising goal, we have a secondary round of renovations planned and we are working on developing partnerships with private investors, the City of Seattle and the Office of Arts and Culture to:

  • Make the space more accessible
  • Increase our event capacity
  • Launch an artist residency / exchange program with CB Toronto
  • Secure the property long-term


Space, Services and Support

We are building a space, but more importantly we've been building a strong community of independent workers. Your contribution will help provide a place for passionate people to connect, to learn and to develop a strong practice.

Together we can provide affordable, accessible workspace to help keep small, local businesses thriving in Capitol Hill.



Other Ways You Can Help

If you have already contributed to our campaign, or if you are unable to contribute financially, there are other ways in which you can help:

  • Share this link with your network of family and friends
  • Help us spread the word - please tell anyone who might be interested
  • Volunteer to help us paint, build furniture, deliver supplies etc.
  • Donate items we are searching for - check our website for the list
  • http://creativeblueprint.ca


Thank you for supporting local artists and entrepreneurs!

story:
Hello, I'm Tiki!  I got into digital art because it interested me and now its my life! I want to step up my game and take my skills to the next level by becoming a full time artist. It's my dream job to work for a company designing characters and backgrounds, but until then i want to be able to work for all the wonderful little people out there. I want to improve myself for all the people who come to me for commissions. 

In the last 5 years i have gone through 3 different laptops! I'm very hard on them and i know a desk top was made for long periods of  use! This is where i'm asking for help! I want a stable work computer that won't die on me every 2 years. Something hardy so i can continue to improve and not worry about replacing a $500+ laptop anymore! I plan on ordering from Cyberpowerpc and building the computer to fit my needs. With your help i can achieve a little part of my dream.

 

Rewards and Cost!


Art coloring book!

This is one of the rewards you get for supporting me. Some perk slots will vary! I am the most excited to get this out to my supporters! It's a picture book most of the pages consist of line art for coloring while a select few pages have fully colored pictures.

STICKERS!!!

Who doesn't love stickers! These are the featured stickers for reward perks! I can send them at random or you can pick which sticker you want, please let me know, if you pick the reward perk with stickers!

PRINTS

Get some wonderfully colored prints! This reward perk is the beez knees! Very high quality work ranging form fan art to my own characters! I will have a list up later in the month with all the prints you can choose from! (all pictures in print examples will be available) 

Your Character Here Page

This is a very Limited reward perk! You get a page in the coloring book of your Original character or favorite media character. In the book it will be just line art but you will get a fully colored digital copy of your character and it will be added to the digital packet of the book as well.

Daki Pillow Case

This Reward perk is Limited! I have yet to finish the one side, but i will have it finished and will update the perk when the pictures is finished! 




The computer im looking at is going to cost me about: $1000

The rewards for contributing will cost about: $2000

  • The Book: $700 to $800
  • The Stickers(3): $100
  • The Prints: $150
  • Daki Pillows: $450
  • Shipping and handling: $200 
  • Other (staples, ink ect): $300
Total= $3,000
I will make sure that everyone who supports me gets what they payed for! All reward perks will be given out before i buy the computer to insure those who helped me know they come first <3


Risks & Challenges

Me and my boyfriend will be putting all the books together by hand, while all the other items will be shipped in to us, before we put the packages together to ship to you. 

There will be a 4-6 month time period before i can start shipping items out. (this includes possible delays) I will updating here on Indiegogo and on other personal media web sites.

Can't Donate But want to Help?

I know money is tight for some people (because i know its tight for me right now) but you can help me by spreading the word or telling a friend about my art, Which you can find: Tumblr(nsfw) | Deviantart | Furaffinity (nsfw) (Nsfw= not safe for work +18)

Thank you so much! I hope you have a wonderful day!

story:
It should be illegal working at 30 degrees during summer, when people sweats and smells. 

We want to be allowed to go to the office wearing swimwear and flip-flops during July and August. 

Join the movement contributing to this cause: you'll receive the kit to start the revolution against the sweat!


The Impact

We can start breathing again!


Risks & Challenges

The only risk is be fired. 

But good news: you can find a job on the beach then! :P


Other Ways You Can Help

- Use deodorant

- Switch on the air conditioning 

- Give us holidays in July and August

story:
*** UPDATE: We have £1060 in total raised in cash and online.***

If we smash our goal, The Attic Arts Centre has pledged to host a FREE weekly community clay workshop, not just to thank everyone for their support and donations, but to give back to you, the community.

***We’re only £540 short!***

We need 108 donations of £5 or 54 donations of £10 


 Hello, My name is Donna. I'm a deaf artist. I've been working with children and schools, running art clubs and projects for the past 8 years and I love it! In March this year I launched an independent Art Centre called, The Attic Arts Centre & Studio.

Top requests from children are:

Can we make with clay? Can we fire the clay? Can we glaze the clay?

But we don't have a kiln of our own!

The kiln is a critical tool, and an enormous investment and commitment. I have the space and my Saturday and School clubs are popular. This term a total of 83 children between the ages of 5 - 12 are attending my classes, each week. In August I ran a series of Kids Art Fun Clubs and drop in Family Creative Hangout events and had close to 200 visits in the studio!


Making with clay was our most popular activity this summer and we're lucky to have access a kiln on a short term basis for small firings. 

We want to continue in January and so we're fundraising for our very own kiln! Can you help us? 

We Really Want A Kiln Campaign 


 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £1,500 to purchase a small electric kiln with shelves and props needed to stack a range of ceramics including hand built ceramics, painted plates and mugs. If we exceed our target, I can buy pottery stock to get our pottery painting classes running, bags of clay, glazes and a potters wheel.

*Approximately 10% of our total raised will go back into Indiegogo to cover Credit Card Fees and is included in the goal amount.

In exchange for your donation, we will make sure you get something for your money! We have ceramic hearts made by kids attending art clubs. They are a bit wonky, but made with 100% love! and lot's more goodies. 

If we don't raise all the funds here, we will keep fundraising till be get all the money needed! We've started raising money already and we have £400 so far!

The Impact

By donating you will be helping to create an environment where people can come to the studio for a class or to drop in and create with love and work with their hands. 

  • With a small electric kiln, myself and guest tutors would be able to run workshops in the studio and visit schools, nurseries and community groups on outreach projects and introducing children & young people to clay  
  • A kiln on site would enable the studio facilitate pottery parties and ceramic workshops which would go along way to covering the costs of the studio lease and making other workshops and art clubs cheaper.

Risks & Challenges

This is my first Indiegogo project. I'm crossing all my fingers and toes and hoping I reach my target here. I'm confident I will raise the money needed because the support from the local community has been huge and it's fantastic to have people involved, spreading the word, rolling up their sleeves, baking cakes to sell and volunteering with workshops.  
If I don't raise all the funds here, I will keep fundraising till I get all the money needed! 
**** UPDATE People ask, is your goal £1600 or £1500? Our goal is £1500 to purchase the kiln and supplies that go with it. Originally I was planning to raise all the money here and I calculated the admin fee based on raising the full amount and so our goal became £1600. I was blown away by the local support. Kids had cake sales and a local pub offered to host a Crafternoon Tea event, Businesses donated raffle prizes and studio visitors donated money. We've raised £935 in cash and so the crowd funding campaign online didn't get a look in. But we are still short so I'm pushing this online campaign now. So my goal is £1500 and I will personally cover the excess charge on the crowd fund campaign. Hope that clears it up!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially and I get that, and there are other ways you can help us. You can still help by spreading the word and making some noise! Invite your friends to like our page, share posts and leave comments about our venue if you've visited. You could have a cake sale, sell unwanted items at your local carboot sale or online. If you are an artist/tutor you could run a workshop and donate your profits. We'll give you the venue! Together we can raise the money and yourself and the community can share the rewards!

Thank you so much for your time and your kind support! Donna xx

A HUGE thank you to filmmaker Anna Cady for making our wonderful film! www.annacady.com

Invite your friends to like our page, share posts and leave comments about our venue if you've visited. You could have a cake sale, sell unwanted items at your local carboot sale or online. If you are an artist/tutor you could run a workshop and donate your profits. We'll give you the venue! Together we can raise the money and yourself and the community can share the rewards!
Thank you so much for your time and your kind support! Donna xx
A HUGE thank you to filmmaker Anna Cady for making our wonderful film! www.annacady.com

story:
I'm staci b - also known as The Haiku Ninja - a literary and visual artist.                                My mission is to connect people to each other, themselves and their environment and I love doing this through Haiku.

Backstory

 I've been writing and sharing the joy of Haiku for twenty years. My adventure with this ancient Japanese art form - a three-line poem with a 5/7/5 syllable structure - reaches new heights with this project! 

Over the years, I've written more than a thousand of these poetic nuggets and they've been read in super cool places, like on Rick Steves Europe and in an Orange County Museum of Art project. For over a decade, I've created art using Haiku that has been seen on numerous platforms.  

Current Story

When the COVID shutdown occurred, I began hosting Haiku Happiness parties on Zoom. Every week, people gathered and spent the first half hour pouring their hearts out about the challenges of navigating the enormous change thrust upon us. Notes were jotted in chat and these words served as a jumping off point to write a collaborative multi-stanza Haiku called a Ku-Ren. But there's a twist!

Instead of everyone writing their own Haiku, I asked for a five-syllable line and wrote down what was offered. Then seven. Then five. Before you knew it, we had ten to twelve Haiku, each written by three different people, representing a cross section of unique experiences about this universal challenge.  

We did this for twelve weeks! At the end of three months, I had over 120 Haiku written by people of all ages, genders, skin colors, and economic backgrounds. Some were figuring out how to work from home, while others had lost their jobs; some lived alone and others were quarantined with roommates or family; there were those who had kids and were navigating home schooling and some who helped take care of others. 

Although our individual experiences were different, the Haiku proved we shared a lot of the same challenges, thoughts and emotions.

Concurrent Story

Each week, after we created the Haiku about the pandemic, we drew inspiration from a piece of art (always with the artist's permission) and then shared our observations. Using those as a starting point, we then developed a Ku-Ren in the same way we did for the shutdown. I then took the original art and the Haiku and designed a new piece of collaborative art! Below is an example of what we created (and what you could do if you get your own private Haiku Happiness Party).  Keep in mind that each Haiku has three authors! If you'd like to see more, you can find a slide show on my site.

________________________________________________________________________

 

Art: Mending by Sara Tang

________________________________________________________________________

Now What?

I knew we had produced something special! It was exciting to share the art Ku-Ren with the artist and across social media. But what could I do with the Haiku about the shutdown? I was at a loss. Then a friend sent me a notice about Corona Crafted, a visual and digital art show in Dormont, PA (right outside Pittsburgh) specifically for work created during the pandemic.

Within a week, an idea showed up for an interactive exhibit that would connect the people who saw the work with those who created it, and anchor the understanding that although we may have different specifics to our experiences, many of our emotions and thoughts are the same. 

I've met with the folks at Flowercity Print Makers, a home grown-locally owned shop, and together we've taken my idea for Welcome to the Future: Interactive Haiku Art - Part One into the production phase.  Because of time constraints, I've chosen to do the first four weeks of what we created and develop the remaining eight weeks later for a larger exhibition.

Your support means that the collaborative work of twenty people will be shared with the world, connecting all of us through art! How cool is that?!

Why It's Important

Sharing this project with the world reinforces that we are not alone in how we think and feel about what will likely be the biggest global challenge of our lifetime. It reminds us of our resiliency, to be kind, laugh and smile - even if it is from behind a mask. 

It nudges us not to ignore the fact that we all struggle and that most of us are doing our best, even if it doesn't look like it sometimes.  Most importantly, it connects us to each other through our humanity - flaws, desires and all.  The best way to understand the universality of a situation is through the specificity and this project accomplishes that.

So You Know...

$350 of the total campaign goes to print and production of the four pieces to be exhibited at the Dormont Corona Crafted Visual and Digital Art Show running August 21-September 20, 2020 at businesses along Liberty and Potomac Avenues in Pittsburgh.

I have budgeted $25 per hour for labor. 

The balance is allocated for framing , hanging the show, Indiegogo fees and time/materials for the perks.

Anything raised over the goal will be put towards the print, production and time needed to create the other eight weeks of  Welcome to the Future: Interactive Haiku Art.

If the goal is not met, I will use what is raised to produce as many of the four pieces as financially possible with the priority being print and production.

PERKS?! Have we got PERKS!!

From a simple social media shout out to hosting your own private Haiku Happiness Party, there is something for everyone! Check out the details on the page and find the one that fits you best.

Potential Hiccups

There's always a small risk that production could get derailed for one reason or another. The good news is the show runs for an entire month, so I'm confident we'll get these four panels hung during the run!

There aren't any guarantees about gathering the financial support, but I'm determined to exhibit as many of the four panels as I can to get started.

As with any project, you can't know what you don't know. What I do know is that I am resourceful and a hardcore networker with a lot connections and believe without a doubt I have what I need to overcome any challenge that might pop up.

Who Is Involved?

The Haiku Collective is comprised of the following intrepid souls who showed up week after week to create this amazing work!

Tina Andrews

Denise Bailey

Kat Belskey

Eric Davidson

AnneLouise Feeny

Pete Fernbaugh

Taylor Meszaros

Mary Randolph

The following contributed their thoughts and feelings over the four-month period:

Evelyn Castillo

Bob Creo

Rossilyne Culgan

Kathleen Donnelly

Ed Gerstenhaber

Bethany Fernbaugh

Libby Kavoulakis

Mandy Minor

Louise Schulhoff

Kay Shapiro

Martha Terry

Deb Wetzler

Other Ways You Can Help

I know things are challenging for some, so if a contribution isn't possible, please share this campaign with your friends, neighbors, family... basically anyone you encounter!

 

 

 

 

​

story:
The Mom Project

My name is Pam and I am a Documentary Photographer, wife, and mother to two teenage girls.  After hearing every female client tell me a million reasons why they didn't feel good enough to be IN photos, I decided enough was enough.  What if I photograph Moms and their kids in a way that makes them FEEL how they are loved, instead of focusing on how they look?  What if all Moms took a break from comparison and judgement and just realized that we are all just doing our best and when we really get down to it, we all want the same things for our kids.  That is my goal with the Mom Project.


I need your help!

  • I have partnered with a local publishing company to write, design, edit and print these images and stories as a hardcover book.  Beautiful enough inside and out to display and full of inspiration for every Mom.
  • Since my family, friends, supporters and clients are the backbone to reaching my goal, I want to give back!
  • If the goal is not met, any money raised will be used to push this project as far as possible.


I want to change the conversation

Fifty years from now, when your children look back at the childhood photographs, will you be in them?  

Do you shy away from the camera because you don't think you are (pick any of the following) skinny enough, pretty enough, hair isn't done, makeup isn't on, clothes aren't good enough and on and on and on?

Will your children see how much you loved them?  

Will your children look through their photos and wonder where you were?

I want to change the conversation.  Stop comparing yourself to other Moms.  We all want the same thing.  We want our children to know we are doing our best, and that we love them more than anything.  I want to publish a book that combines images of Mother/Child connection side by side with stories from real Moms about their joys and worries in Motherhood.  

It's a big big deal.

I realize that this is a big dream, with hefty goals.  I whole heartedly believe in the message of this project.  This needs to be seen.  I can't do this alone.

  • The Mom Project began in 2013 and I have been committed to photographing Moms and their children ever since.
  • I plan on expanding my portfolio to include Moms of all kinds.  There will truly be something that every Mom can relate to.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Can't help financially? That's ok! Please share this campaign!
